items.text: Neo Electronic PopFrom Ray of Light to BRAT, pop records have long repurposed club culture to delight the masses. But in 2025, a sort of reverse osmosis emerged: cutting-edge producers found new avenu
items.description: Neo Electronic PopFrom Ray of Light to BRAT, pop records have long repurposed club culture to delight the masses. But in 2025, a sort of reverse osmosis emerged: cutting-edge producers found new avenues for experimentation in pop's effervescent packaging. From Shanti Celeste's glossy love songs on Romance to Oli XL's K-pop meets IDM on Lick The Lens, there's a clear uptick in the use of radio-ready melodies. In a moment when big-room dance music is more mainstream (and more mind-numbing) than ever, underground artists returned to pop as a point of subversion; a new way to enliven drum & bass, trance and trip-hop without sullying the source material.The relationship between pop and dance music dates back to the '80s, when artists like Boy George and The Human League first conceived of pop as a self-aware art form, not a chart metric. Their vision was fuelled by the same anti-establishment spirit that influenced club innovators like Larry Heard and Underground Resistance. In 2025, pop sounds more in line with that original art punk mentality than it has in decades. There's always been pop worth dancing to, but it's been a long time since so many skilled dance music producers have contributed to the cause.– Hattie LindertRecord of the YearOklouchoke enoughThe off‑centre vaporwave pop songs on Oklou's radical debut make for perfect bedroom music. The French musician's hypnagogic dream logic and tender harmonies render life's most existential moments with microscopic precision and a lulling calm. "endless" opens like a beacon from a far‑off village, her dulcet, auto‑tuned vocals shutting out all notifications from the outside world. "thank you for recording" turns surveillance into a lullaby, while "blade bird" crystallises the album's themes of attachment and harm into weightless nursery rhymes. In the background hum of 2025's global crises, this kind of dissociative dream pop feels spot on, turning panic into an exquisitely arranged experience. This is a record for soft clubbing; for dreamers who want the night to blur rather than explode.– Gio SantiagoRead the full reviewListen:BandcampRecordskeiyaAhooke's lawIt's rare to be transported inside an artist's head. keiyaA's second album is so expressive that listeners can almost hear her neurons crackling as she crafts track after track of achingly intimate music. It's like reading her diary, while also pilfering her drug stash. The Chicago-raised artist translates the chaos of heartbreak, self-doubt, rage and mental illness into a brilliant bricolage of experimental pop and R&B. These 19 cuts are surreal and unsettling, but also raw and truthful, portraying soul music as both escapism and catharsis.– Cameron CookRead the full reviewListen:BandcampPinkPantheressFancy ThatPinkPantheress crashed into 2025 with a mixtape that supercharged the London producer's breakbeat-driven sound. Her recognisable traits—a core palette of UKG, jungle, drum & bass; Y2K-era samples, conversational vocals—remain, but overall, Fancy That is so bold and bright that it feels like a reinvention. Hands-in-the-air moments, faster tempos and peak-time melodies are abundant. With surprise summer hits like the Underworld-sampling "Illegal" and the Groove Armada-inspired "Stateside," the young luminary proved she can go from being an internet star to the leader of club-pop's next generation.– Shaad D'SouzaRead the full reviewListen:SpotifyTracksFKA twigs"Girl Feels Good"Eusexua is all about revelation—the sensation of finding your true self "under a hard metal silver stiletto on the damp rave floor." On "Girl Feels Good," the album's trip-hop highlight, the UK multi-hyphenate celebrates this sentiment with unbridled joy. Over brooding guitar and an entrancing techno-pop chorus, she sings how a woman's blossoming pleasure can fill a night with infinite potential. A proper ode to female desire, this is a song as sacred as it is profane.– Vrinda JagotaRead the full reviewListen:SpotifyRochelle Jordan"Bite The Bait"Rochelle Jordan's sixth album, Through The Wall, served a masterclass in assured and sexy house with a pop sheen. "Bite The Bait," produced by regular collaborator Jimmy Edgar, is a late-night R&B jam where the Chicago artist's teasing, honeyed soprano drips over stripped-back drums."Pulled up to the party it was me, myself and I / Breaking hella hearts I didn't even have to try," she sings, radiating a quiet confidence that carries the track right from the club to the afters at dawn.– Katie ThomasListen:BandcampMixbambinodjLIVE FROM EARTH Mix 79If you've fallen for the hazy alt-pop of Oklou or Malibu, you'll find a kindred spirit in bambinodj. His music welds the Black diasporic sounds of shatta, amapiano and Flex Dance Music with trance, ambient and IDM. These aren't genres that a DJ would typically pair, but in bambinodj's world, it makes perfect sense. This mix encapsulates his sonic DNA: downtempo Balearic haze, inscrutable SoundCloud oddities, Caribbean rhythms and majestic piano leads that put Marc Cohn's Walking in Memphis to shame.– Fahad AkinsanyaListen:SoundCloudFurther ListeningSudan ArchivesThe BPMListen:BandcampJim Legxacyblack british music (2025)Listen:BandcampFcukers"Play Me"Listen:BandcampGeorge Riley"Private Life"Listen:SpotifyMalibuUnited In Flames w/ JAMESJAMESJAMESListen:SoundCloudListen to the Neo Electronic Pop playlistSpotify

items.text: Noise DistortionDance music's edges have frayed in fascinating ways in 2025. Whether an attempt to make sense of a world still vibrating with instability, or simply a rejection of the overpolished clu
items.description: Noise DistortionDance music's edges have frayed in fascinating ways in 2025. Whether an attempt to make sense of a world still vibrating with instability, or simply a rejection of the overpolished club tools that continue to flood the scene, some of the year's best releases have been forged from the cracks—records that find beauty in disintegration.At the centre of this shift is a renewed fascination with noise and distortion, not only as sonic aesthetic but as emotional language. Disparate artists seem to be drawn to sounds that carry strain, abrasion or a sense of dislocation. Distortion communicates pressure—be that in a personal sense or wider communities navigating upheaval. Even when artists such as Los Thuthanaka or aya pushed their palettes into raw or blown-out territory, it was less about harshness for its own sake and more about revealing what lay beneath the polish.Equally, distortion took on a more introspective bent. Producers working in slower or more reflective modes—Klein, DJ Haram, Rainy Miller—leaned into erosion as a kind of emotional texture. Their use of noise suggested memory slipping, feelings blurring, structures softening rather than breaking.While far from a new phenomenon, perhaps this turn toward noise is a response to an era defined by overstimulation. Amid algorithmic smoothness and endless playlists, distortion feels like something human again. It restores the club's physicality: a reminder that dance music has always thrived on what doesn't quite fit, on frequencies that shake your body as much as they move your feet.– Michael LawsonRecord of the YearLos ThuthanakaLos ThuthanakaUnless you experience synesthesia, listening to Los Thuthanaka might be the closest you'll get to seeing sound. Digitised Andean folk music brings to mind brown mountains and deep blue lakes, while corroded synths are redlined to evoke a radioactive lime green. The first collaborative album from siblings Joshua Crampton and Chuquimamani-Condori melds Andean folk, queer psychedelia and staticky ambient into an ultra-digital experience. Crampton's chugging electric guitar provides the bedrock, setting the atmosphere ablaze while Chuquimamani-Condori gets busy with their sampler, adding bursts of humour via cartoonish, pitched-down voices yelling "Yo!" or "Grrrrr!" over sun-dappled rhythms. These crackling loops become heaving, transcendental waves of sound, haptic feedback sent all the way down from their ancestors.– Kiana MicklesRead the full reviewListen:BandcampRecordsayahexed!Trauma scuffs your spirit, the way an explosion leaves your ears ringing. aya's mesmerising second album seeks to confront her past battles with substance addiction head-on and out loud. The album is rife with one detonation after another, conveying the dark side of the never-ending afters. Muddy digital roar becomes purifying fire; the feedback of a siren's call pulls you in like a friend begging you to party. But listen through to the end of the record, and you'll hear the victorious sound of newfound self-control.– Jesse DorrisRead the full reviewListen:BandcampDJ KRadio Libertadora !On his debut LP, PANICO NO SUBMUNDO, São Paulo producer DJ K made as much noise as possible, defying conservative efforts to silence Brazilian funk with walls of tuin-tinged sub-bass unique to bruxaria, his preferred strain. His second album, Radio Libertadora !, focuses more on favela life and its anarchy. He raps about the daughter of a doctor who chooses to be a marginal (thug) on "SOBREVIVE CONTRA O ESTADO," his words ringing loud and clear above the fanfare. For DJ K, noise is freedom.– Joseph FrancisRead the full reviewListen:BandcampTracksDJ Haram"Fishnets feat. Bbymutha, SHA RAY & August Fanon""Fishnets," the third single on DJ Haram's debut album Beside Myself, plays with opacity. Over buckling 808s, a warped Arabic violin conveys that dissolution itself might be an exercise in control. DJ Haram and August Fanon's enigmatic boom bap is a thrilling vehicle for Bbymutha and SHA RAY's cocky-yet-gleeful verses. "Fishnets" is a testament to the survival of the spirit as an artist grappling with a global hellscape. Squaring up to the stale systems in power has never sounded more infectious.– Isabel LingRead the full reviewListen:BandcampKlein"blood on the flag""blood on the flag" closes out Klein's bludgeoning guitar record, thirteen sense, with a mixture of desperation and righteous fury. Norwegian black metal levels of serrated fuzz bleed into midrange frequencies, while boisterous drums cut the wall of hiss before everything vanishes in a rush of glissando. It feels as if the previous 37 minutes sublimate into air: the track's final howl reduced to a breeze blowing through wind chimes, a fragile calm earned through terrifying catharsis. In other words: this, too, shall pass.– Andrew RyceRead the full reviewListen:BandcampMixmi-elIn Dreams for The Trilogy TapesA gloomy XXYYXX classic sits beside an Alan Watts speech, a horny Outkast track is saddled next to heavy breathing. mi-el's In Dreams is viscerally unnerving. But peak freak arrives an hour in, as she judders from aya's ketamine-induced paranoia to the experimental rap of Conway The Machine like it's the most natural transition in the world. Darkly mesmerising, the mix feels like a personalised hand-me-down from a sibling, meant to keep you up at night while shaping your taste.– Tom GledhillListen:SoundCloudFurther ListeningJane RemoverRevengeseekerzRead the reviewListen:BandcampDJ TravellaTwende - Dance ClassicsListen:BandcampDebit"La Ronda y el sonidero"Read the reviewListen:SoundCloudSkrillex"ANDY"Read the reviewListen:SpotifysoftburnObjet Personnel w/ softburnListen:SoundCloudListen to the Noise Distortion playlistSpotify

items.text: Guitar JamsRight now, guitars are everywhere in electronic music, a reflection of the great blending of genres that's defined the past five years. In 2025, albums were rarely anchored to one sound, of
items.description: Guitar JamsRight now, guitars are everywhere in electronic music, a reflection of the great blending of genres that's defined the past five years. In 2025, albums were rarely anchored to one sound, often enlisting the malleable quality of the guitar to transform electronic beats into rock ballads. As one of the oldest instruments, guitars can provoke a jolt of time-worn emotion. That tug on the heart when you hear a lonely minor key? Practically baked into human DNA. Ambling post-rock arpeggios can inspire visions of pastoral terrain, while an indie-pop glissando might give you a new lease of life. Fans clamour to see Smerz's dramatic live rendition of "You got time and I got money," while at home they hit replay for the moping chords that stretch out below the duo's honeyed lyrics.Rock faded out of the mainstream in the late '00s, as EDM, rap and pop surged across the next decade. The genre struggled to reclaim its place in the zeitgeist, until a post-pandemic malaise stalked the music industry and everyone reached for their guitars. Copenhagen—which, in addition to Smerz, is home to Astrid Sonne, ML Buch and Erika de Casier—led the charge. Using the guitar as a textural tool, these artists built layers atop introspective electronic foundations. They bottled a year of political turmoil and economic decline into songs that felt double-sided, capturing a youthful angst alongside a yearning for something, anything, more.– Kiana MicklesRecord of the Yearjames KFriendOn Friend, Jamie Krasner wields her guitar with the freedom of an acrobat flying through the air. Using space to transformative effect, she defies expectations of electronic pop songwriting through her mastery of genre. Wispy tones lap gently against glowing reverbed vocals, bringing an expansive feel to the album's unique strain of ethereality.There's no doubt Krasner can shred in a more classic indie rock vein (see "On God"'s swathes of dream pop chords), but where she really excels is in transforming the guitar altogether through sampling and meticulously applied FX. Whether it's chugging alongside the peppy heartbeat drums on "Play," sputtering over choral vocal samples on the cavernous "Rider" or undulating at the core of trip-hoppy "Blinkmoth (July Mix)," her guitar shapeshifts throughout Friend's electronic landscape as mutably as a synth could.– Sue ParkRead the full reviewListen:BandcampRecordsAcopiaBlush ResponseAcopia's third album is a shimmering haze of shoegaze guitars and soft, yearning vocals. Moving away from the drum programming and grittier, bass-driven sound of previous records, Blush Response revels in downtempo, sparse grooves and cool-headed trip-hop. Vocalist Kate Durman channels her lilting soubrette over distorted fuzz, reverb-laden guitar tones and the wonky harmonics of tracks like "Chase Me" and "Let Down." The album is a dreamlike, wafting soundworld seen through bleary eyes.– Ammar KaliaRead the full reviewListen:BandcampJoanne RobertsonBlurrrIn a year full of albums that sound like they might have drifted from an abandoned campsite, Blurrr distinguishes itself with the subtle spectrum of sound it teases from everyday tools. The UK musician's guitar groans in her hands as much as it sings, always a low, solid counterweight to her floating and translucent voice. This is an album that envelopes you like mist: slowly, imperceptibly, until all of a sudden it's all you can see.– Sasha GeffenRead the full reviewListen:BandcampTracksSmerz"You got time and I got money"On "You got time and I've got money," Smerz cement their claim to Scandi fame. It's the Copenhagen duo's own "Bittersweet Symphony," an orchestral love song that documents the thrill of a new relationship. Although the track's smoky bass guitar plucks a refrain in D minor sharp—the key of mourning—it still lands as a serene dispatch from the honeymoon phase, all warm embraces and waking up together. Over the smoothest drumline of the year, Catharina Stoltenberg and Henriette Motzfeldt wallow in a grounded romance: patient, consistent and built to endure.– Hattie LindertListen:BandcampNourished By Time"Max Potential"The brazen heart of "Max Potential" is riven: between passion and resignation, romance and staying true to oneself. This standout from Nourished By Time's fantastic second album, The Passionate Ones, establishes a remarkable sweep. The Baltimore singer teases out love's inherent freneticism, while the arrangements shift wildly—a frantic dynamic for frantic times. Eventually, the protean musical sensibility whips the urgent central lyric, "If I'm gonna go insane / At least I'm loved by you," into a mantra for the steadfast and enamoured. The effect is irresistible.– Daniel FelsenthalRead the full reviewListen:BandcampMixLogic1000DJ​-​Kicks: Logic1000Conceived as a "little piece of serenity," Logic1000's dreamy, zoned-out mix for !K7's iconic DJ-Kicks series wrapped us in a cocoon, capturing the mood for all things downtempo across a vapour trail of ambient dub, of-the-moment trip-hop and esoteric Scandi pop. Leaning into picks from some of 2025's most talked-about artists—james K, Smerz, Purelink, Oklou, Blood Orange and Yves Tumor—the Australian producer and DJ turned in a guitar-laced tincture of self-care, swapping house bangers for home-listening gems.– April Clare WelshRead the full reviewListen:BandcampFurther ListeningModel / ActrizPirouetteRead the reviewListen:BandcampBlood OrangeEssex HoneyRead the reviewListen:SpotifySaffron Bloom"Flame Never Dies"Listen:BandcampRaisa K"Stay feat. Cobey Sey"Listen:BandcampMoMA ReadyCROSSWALKS: 100% CD MIXListen:SoundCloudListen to the Guitar Jams playlistSpotify

Using space to transformative effect, she defies expectations of electronic pop songwriting through her mastery of genre. Wispy tones lap gently against glowing reverbed vocals, bringing an expansive feel to the album's unique strain of ethereality.There's no doubt Krasner can shred in a more classic indie rock vein (see "On God"'s swathes of dream pop chords), but where she really excels is in transforming the guitar altogether through sampling and meticulously applied FX. Whether it's chugging alongside the peppy heartbeat drums on "Play," sputtering over choral vocal samples on the cavernous "Rider" or undulating at the core of trip-hoppy "Blinkmoth (July Mix)," her guitar shapeshifts throughout Friend's electronic landscape as mutably as a synth could.– Sue ParkRead the full reviewListen:Bandcamp

items.text: Nourished By Time"Max Potential"The brazen heart of "Max Potential" is riven: between passion and resignation, romance and staying true to oneself. This standout from Nourished By Time's fantastic sec
items.description: Nourished By Time"Max Potential"The brazen heart of "Max Potential" is riven: between passion and resignation, romance and staying true to oneself. This standout from Nourished By Time's fantastic second album, The Passionate Ones, establishes a remarkable sweep. The Baltimore singer teases out love's inherent freneticism, while the arrangements shift wildly—a frantic dynamic for frantic times. Eventually, the protean musical sensibility whips the urgent central lyric, "If I'm gonna go insane / At least I'm loved by you," into a mantra for the steadfast and enamoured. The effect is irresistible.– Daniel FelsenthalRead the full reviewListen:Bandcamp

items.text: Logic1000DJ​-​Kicks: Logic1000Conceived as a "little piece of serenity," Logic1000's dreamy, zoned-out mix for !K7's iconic DJ-Kicks series wrapped us in a cocoon, capturing the mood for all things do
items.description: Logic1000DJ​-​Kicks: Logic1000Conceived as a "little piece of serenity," Logic1000's dreamy, zoned-out mix for !K7's iconic DJ-Kicks series wrapped us in a cocoon, capturing the mood for all things downtempo across a vapour trail of ambient dub, of-the-moment trip-hop and esoteric Scandi pop. Leaning into picks from some of 2025's most talked-about artists—james K, Smerz, Purelink, Oklou, Blood Orange and Yves Tumor—the Australian producer and DJ turned in a guitar-laced tincture of self-care, swapping house bangers for home-listening gems.– April Clare WelshRead the full reviewListen:Bandcamp

items.text: Club HeatersAt the end of every year, we usually identify a single track that seemed to unite every club and festival stage. Think Maya Jane Coles' "What They Say," Kassem Mosse's "Untitled (A1)" or J
items.description: Club HeatersAt the end of every year, we usually identify a single track that seemed to unite every club and festival stage. Think Maya Jane Coles' "What They Say," Kassem Mosse's "Untitled (A1)" or Joy Orbison's 2024 smash "flight fm," tracks that sliced clean through our imagined trenches and could make any dance floor move in unison.In 2025, it felt like that moment never quite materialised. Don't get us wrong: the absence of a unanimous dance floor heater doesn't mean there wasn't a slew of excellent club music coming out. It's more that the heat got more localised. It's long been true that what goes off in, say, New York, stands apart from what works in Ibiza, and this year, those differences made the notion of a single, standout club anthem untenable.The lack of universal hits, however, meant more breathing room. This year, the producers soundtracking peak-time moments have stayed small, specific and rooted. For the cohort revelling against AI slop, algorithmic sameness and other homogenising forces, the result was a landscape defined by artistic pluralism and local autonomy rather than one-size-fits-all trends.This shift hints at progress. The appetite for hard and fast persists, sure, but it mutated, shaped by space, crowd and context. Instead of one monolithic sound dominating the scene, you get micro-moments: whether that be the Come Round EP by DJ PGZ & Yikes, two Aboriginal producers staking their claim on the sound of Australian dance floors and bush doofs; or Kiara Scuro and Sugar Free, whose respective releases channelled a sleazy, slow-burning chug familiar to anyone who has clocked in hours at fabric or Houghton. A welcome reminder that the notion of peak time can—and should—offer something different for every floor.– Bella AquilinaRecord of the YearDJ PGZ & YikesCome RoundCome Round has the unbridled energy of a peak-time dance floor coursing through it. Gunai/Kurnai and Yorta Yorta artist DJ PGZ and Boorloo-based Wongi artist Yikes forged their bond in underground spaces—from DJ PGZ attending formative queer parties to inviting Yikes to play his first set at Sub Club in Naarm. Here, that early spark comes full circle. Across solo cuts, cross-remixes and a standout joint track, "Ouss Ouss," the release maps two artists searching for, and ultimately locking into, unity in their respective sounds.It's full throttle from the get‑go: all big, wubby basslines, fierce vocal chops and swirling crescendos that summon the kind of feral inhibition only a grimy basement can unlock. DJ PGZ's pulsing hard techno interlocks with Yikes's spacious, trance-leaning grooves, all threaded by percussive broken beats. The result captures a powerful moment, as two First Nations producers propel Australian dance music into its next chapter.– Hannah DoodyListen:BandcampRecordsKiara ScuroNight Crush​​On Kassian's Rinse FM show in February, Rosie Ama described Night Crush, the debut (and final) Kiara Scuro EP, as "an ode to being on the dance floor when you don't really know what time it is." That disoriented thrill runs through all three tracks: the haziness of heavy reverb and the way the deep, rolling grooves lock your body into the rhythm. Every so often, a repeating riff on opener "Witching Hour" invites that movement, murmuring "body, in motion." File this one with your favourite Planet Euphorique releases.– Katie ThomasListen:BandcampSugar FreeDisociandoJust like her DJ sets, Sugar Free's debut EP squirms with amoebic movement. Disociando's prog house and tech house cuts swell and contract like jellyfish in water, balancing moments of hips-swaying bliss with heads-down enthralment. Pared-back drums add tension and a touch of sleaze, while gorgeous textural details—oddball synth burbles and feedback buildups—bring a zany experimentalism into the mix. This striking amalgam of psychedelia, minimal house and bounce is a peak-time treat with grit and groove, but it's also slinky enough to work the afters.– Nyshka ChandranRead the full reviewListen:BandcampTracksWOST"Banda"Not "banda" as in band, but as in crew. This Spanish translation nails the mantra of the global posse that WOST and Colombian label TraTraTrax have been rallying over the years. On "Banda," the Bogotá-based producer unleashes a percussive cut that's travelled from Video Club to Rinse FM. There's FM synthesis, a drum breakdown and a sped-up dembow tresillo beat so syncopated it sounds like it might mutate into dubstep with each bar. As the gap between the Latin American and UK undergrounds keeps closing, "Banda" proves electronic fusion never has to dilute flavour.– Rachel Grace AlmeidaListen:BandcampJump Source"On (feat. Martyn Bootyspoon)"Patrick Holland and Priori have been quietly producing with other artists—like james K and Physical Therapy—from their Montreal studio. They've still had time to crank out earworms like "On," a euphoric club track so infectious it disarms even the most dedicated techno purists. The confluence of Jump Source's meticulous production and Martyn Bootyspoon's signature vocal swagger is a showcase in style that feels both retro-futurist and viscerally current. In a sense, it's the sound of 2025—a reach for nostalgic sounds that sits undeniably in the present.– Chloe LulaListen:BandcampMixDJ Tobzy Imole GiwaLagos City UnloadedThe algorithm demands bitesized clips of DJs blending belters together. You can either curse this tyranny, or do like DJ Tobzy Imole Giwa does and exaggerate the formula. On Lagos City Unloaded, the cruise beat DJ blitzes through hyperspeed pop, R&B and Eurodance alongside continental genres like Afrobeat, kwaito and amapiano. During one flurry, Lil Wayne's famous "A Milli" a capella creeps in with the subtlety of Looney Tunes's Sylvester before being ousted by the Tweety Bird-pitched trill of Yves Larock's "Rise Up." As DJ Tobzy pushes everything he touches to cartoonish extremes, he makes disparate genres find copious common ground.– Joseph FrancisListen:BandcampFurther ListeningBaaltiMelaRead the reviewListen:BandcampPloyIt's Later Than You ThinkRead the reviewListen:BandcampKhadija Al Hanafi"Bounce It On The Flo"Listen:BandcampJSPORT"No Turning Back"Listen:BandcampKontronatura b2b Nick LeónCarnaval Novo AffairListen:SoundCloudListen to the Club Heaters playlistSpotify

items.title: The House of Crocodiles
items.label: Live at Freerotation
items.description: Halfway through Nono Gigsta's sequel to her 2018 Freerotation set, also named The House of Crocodiles, we get an indication of the strange title's origins. "The males' rippling flesh sends soundwaves through the water… humans can barely hear them, but the crocodiles can. Welcome to the House of Crocodiles," a sample narrates. And then, oh so naturally, it moves into a roaring electric guitar solo (Led Zeppelin's "Whole Lotta Love"). It's a bonkers move that can prompt you to completely rethink what DJing can be. It's also completely natural in the hands of the Belgian DJ.Jaw-dropping transitions dominate this two-hour recording, aptly described as "Big Blend Academy" by one commenter. Low-end frequencies anchor the mix as it darts through wild variations in mood and tempo. Dubwise experiments (LUXE's "Diamond Dub") morph into frenetic jazz techno (Gigi FM's "Gabriella"), sounding like DJ Sprinkles if she dabbled in UK bass. You can feel Gigsta's sense of freedom as she aqueously glides across loose and liquid rhythms.Freewheeling mixes of this sort often risk being overly headsy, but this is a very fun listen that spans Björk, Foster Sylvers and Victoria Monet. The inclusion of more "popular music" only adds to the overwhelming sense of feverish delight. There's only one reasonable response to a mix this audacious: "WTF." - Bella Aquilina

items.title: Sound Metaphors
items.label: Refuge Worldwide
items.description: Chucheewa, one-half of Bangkok duo Acid Sister, thrives in slow tempos where she can flex her storytelling skills. In this mix, she's the sonic embodiment of an off-duty femme fatale. Balearic downtempo, acid house, dubby disco and woozy krautrock criss-cross one another like whispery marble veins, transporting listeners to a sleek, '70s-style disco where our protagonist is getting her lounge on. There's a nonchalant swagger underlining every track, as if mirroring her breezy movements. The mood is loose-limbed but there's a high degree of intellect and intention behind each rhythm, just like a Bond girl's alluringly sharp demeanour. - Nyshka Chandran

items.title: Episode 65
items.label: There Is No Planet Earth
items.description: For Black History Month, New York's JADALAREIGN explored the myriad shades of deep house through a futurist lens. Selections emphasise the radical spirit behind Black music-making, whether via icy, austere melodies or the psychedelic squelches of 303s. Cruising through under-the-radar classics (Felix Da Housecat's "Free Love") and curveballs (Sweater on Polo's "Computer Controlled Madness"), the Nowadays booker zones in on tunes with a spacey touch that often borders on kooky (just look at Marcus Mixx's twisted jack track "Salut The Noize With A Laugh"). This is a concise but essential glimpse into the innovative imaginations of Chicago and Detroit artists, past and present. - Nyshka Chandran

items.title: One Hour of IICON
items.label: FMB Mixtape 243
items.description: If you caught our Glastonbury recap from earlier this year, you'll already know that Mia Koden's opening set at the IICON stage was something special. A "blend of celestial, 2562-esque dubstep backdropped by a beautiful sunset," as one RA staffer put it. For FMB, the London-based artist condensed that two-and-a-half-hour set into this lean power-hour of soulful sub-pressure. Just listen to the way she moves from the soothing resplendence of Ella Fitzgerald to the dank 140 of Slimy, Delta and Obskure within the opening ten minutes. Anything's possible in Mia Koden's capable hands. - Tom Gledhill

items.title: Dekmantel Podcast 459
items.description: 2024 was a career-defining year for Canadian DJ and producer Priori, whose entry into the vaunted Dekmantel series blooms with spiralling, psychedelia-dipped sound design. This 90-minute session bears more resemblance to a longform song than a tapestry of different ones, applying incredible attention to detail by collaging deep and squelchy textures that sit as much in the future as they do in the past. If a snapshot could be taken of the styles that reigned 2024's dance floors, it's this: an incredibly cohesive and soft-hued marriage of nimble breakbeats, techno and trance from an artist going from strength to strength. - Chloe Lula

items.title: Floresta
items.label: Live at Waking Life
items.description: The appeal of a festival lies in its promise of escape from the mundane, and there's perhaps no better soundtrack to this promise than Reptant. A key figure in the electro revival, the Melbourne producer is known for a sleek, omnivorous sound that blends elements of tech house, trance and techno. His powers shine in this live recording from Portugal's Waking Life festival, which brims with otherworldly ambience. One standout at the 22-minute mark sounds as if Mike Skinner and Plastikman made an electro record together. Reptant later called it his "most special" gig ever. Check the SoundCloud comments and you'll see the dancers agree. - Bella Aquilina

items.title: The Lot × Kiosk
items.label: Live at Horst
items.description: DJ SWISHA is currently operating at the peak of his powers. With a doctorate-level grasp of Black American dance music and UK breakbeat, he's a true mixologist with a PhD in tearing up the club. This recording proves it. Effortlessly weaving through East Coast club, ghetto house, jungle and footwork, there's an enviable ease to every blend. The feral crowd noise is the perfect cherry on top—each transition is met with unrestrained whoops and cheers. Aspiring club DJs, take notes: this is a masterclass in how it's done. - Fahad Akinsanya

items.title: FACT mix 938
items.description: Full disclosure: this one actually landed in December 2023. But because it slipped through the cracks of year-end coverage, and the legendary mix series shut down weeks later, we decided to bend the rules. Plus, it's totally mesmerising, the kind of mix that triggers 1,000 wormholes and—should you listen in a particularly fragile state—possibly floods of tears. This is bold, cinematic, heart-on-sleeve DJing. A long ambient first half features tracks from Ulla, Burial and Slikback before morphing into headbanging mode with shards of Verraco, Eartheater and Lil Wayne. Stick this on when you really want to feel something. - Carlos Hawthorn

items.title: Live at Draaimolen Festival
items.description: DJ Travella is the face of singeli's future. The Dar Es Salaam artist infuses techno and taarab into the famously hi-NRG genre, adding a touch of experimentalism and contemporary rave to its frenzied tempos. For many in attendance, this was a clear highlight of Draaimolen Festival and it's easy to understand why. His vibrant selections possess a sense of urgency, commanding movement through jolting synths and madcap effects. The crowd vibed so hard that Travella ended up dancing on top of the decks—a perfect picture of singeli's joyful nature. - Nyshka Chandran

items.title: Misantropical
items.label: Rinse France
items.description: Three things are guaranteed when these two subversive powerhouses link up: an onslaught of Latin-infused bass trax, coquettish flexes about diva behaviour and an involuntary desire to throw ass. Venezuelan rave doll Yajaira La Beyaca has been on a tear since 2021, but this hybrid live set—one of her first in Europe—alongside frequent collaborator Genosidra, demonstrates an artist fully stepping into her powers. Darting through apocalyptic perreo, guaracha and what some call Latincore, this session is a soundtrack for all your freaky pre-club rituals. When Genosidra slips into a speed dembow refix of JME's "If You Don't Know"? Proof that perfection does exist. - Rachel Grace Almeida

items.title: Bomb Tech 49
items.label: Eastern Margins
items.description: Like gqom and raptor house, budots is finally joining the modest list of regional dance music genres gaining global recognition. Originating in the Philippines in the early '00s, the street-pioneered sound combines trancey techno and house with fat bass, high-pitched synths and lots of air horns.Now, pioneer DJ Love is showing off a new mutation of the classic sound with "Bomb Tech 49." Fittingly called bomb-tek, this offshoot is more techno-driven and undeniably harder, darker and leaner. Whereas the traditional stylings tend to be chirpier and whimsical, blippy effects, this strain, full of springy basslines and looped drums, takes budots off the streets and into the club. - Nyshka Chandran

items.title: In My Dreams (Powerhouse Mix)
items.label: Eskimo/N.E.W.S.
items.description: "In My Dreams (Powerhouse Mix)" is the early '90s Italo house classic that never was. Pairing sugary, Latin freestyle-inspired vocals with huge piano stabs à la 4 For Money's "It's a Moment in Time," it's the kind of turn-of-the-decade anthem you'd expect to hear soundtracking grainy archival footage from Cocoricò or Quadrant Park.Except "In My Dreams" isn't from the '90s—it's a new release from contemporary synth pop outfit Nuovo Testamento. Dismiss it as frivolous if you like, but doing so won't diminish the truth: this track is custom-made for massive, life-affirming rave moments. - Michael Lawson

items.title: Temple Arp
items.label: Dekmantel
items.description: Like many great techno tracks, "Temple Arp" is a marathon, not a sprint. Stretching out over seven minutes, this beatific roller hooks you in with a cosmic intro that builds tension like a thriller. Sam Goku's previous releases, such as 2021's Tanggu and 2021's East Dimensional Riddims, have demonstrated the Munich-based producer's eye for the finer details."Temple Arp" is the stunning zenith of this meticulous approach: softly padded kicks and constellations of otherworldly synths work seamlessly to lull you into a trance, plotting a dubby voyage of epic proportions that favours nuance over heft. - April Clare Welsh

items.title: Not Here For It
items.label: Morph Tracks
items.description: It's one thing to produce a dance track. It's quite another to permeate it with the sheer essence of the club, transporting listeners to the dankest dance floor they've ever been on. Atlanta-based producer Leonce's incandescent banger "Not Here For It" uses effervescent keyboard arpeggios and infectious diva vocal samples ("here, here for you") to convey bodily liberation on a visceral level.When the beat drops, you can almost feel the sweat bead on your brow, as Leonce flexes not only his production chops, but his keen understanding of what makes the most seasoned ravers go off. - Cameron Cook

items.title: Boys
items.label: untitled (recs)
items.description: Nothing hits like a sexy a cappella line—and TAAHLIAH and singer Elouiza delivered on "Boys." Fans of TAAHLIAH's bolshy, playful DJ sets may have been surprised by the introspection of her debut LP, Gramarye, but TAAHLIAH still made room for "Boys," the glossy, seductive club cut she's been teasing since 2022.Elouiza's smouldering vocal—"These boys, they all want me / They all want to get in me"—is adorned with a growling bassline, crashing kick drums and plasticky neon synths, resulting in a perfect balance of cheeky yet tough. If 2024 served us up a track for stomping around the city feeling hot, this is it. - Katie Thomas

items.title: Del Salsódromo al Rave
items.label: self-released
items.description: What happens when you throw "Talento de Televisión" by salsa legend Willie Colón into a blender with Nightcrawlers' '90s house anthem "Push the Feeling On"? Possibly the most fun you can have on a dance floor.Mexican producer 1OO1O has been steadily ascending with his tropi-fusions of salsa and breaks, expertly folding the Caribbean genre's rhythmic principles into techno and bass music—all with a puckish wink. But "Del Salsódromo al Rave" takes this formula and intensifies the flavour. A base layer of Nightcrawlers' immediately recognisable synth line, a dash of Colón's warming trumpet ensemble, all bound by pummelling, hip-vitalising kicks at 150 BPM. Delicioso. - Rachel Grace Almeida

items.title: Seismic Activity
items.label: ec2a
items.description: The global club music cross-pollination was in full flow long before Miami duo INVT and neo-garage innovator Introspekt decided to make music together, but the resulting EP, Tectónica, is nevertheless one of the explosive statements in recent memory.It's a quality three-tracker, but opening cut "Seismic Activity" is the one that truly stands out as the jewel in the crown. The trio find a rousing middle ground between their respective styles of Latin-fortified tech house and buoyant UKG, enhanced by a slowed-down sample from Salt-N-Pepa's "Push It." This is dark and lusty 2-step capable of, well, shattering dance floors the world over. - Michael Lawson

items.title: SPANK!
items.label: Loma Vista
items.description: HiTech know how to keep cool under pressure. This is key to the trio's marriage of heart-palpitating ghettotech with laid-back rapping: their ability to float atop 150 BPM sizzlers with pure control. "SPANK!" pushes that contrast to the max, overlaying a dizzying central bongo loop with programmed keys, synth flares and laser FX.But it runs on GDMRW and King Milo's verses, traded off drill-style in attempts at getting their hands on a triple threat: "She got beauty / She got brains / She got booty all in that thang." Sure, "bend it over, let me spank," isn't the subtlest come-on, but HiTech's flow makes it seem almost elegant. The end result is as sexy and tactile as the palm-to-ass communion. - Hattie Lindert

items.title: please 5 more minutes
items.label: Thrill Jockey
items.description: There is an inherent melancholy in having to ask for more time; an underlying sense of defeat in prolonging the inevitable. And though experimental composer Claire Rousay is not above having to “beg” for it, as she candidly croons on electronic ballad “please 5 more minutes”—a standout from this year's sentiment—she wrings clear-eyed dignity out of an act of vulnerability.Combining purposeful guitar with heavily Auto-Tuned vocals, Rousay modifies the self-described "emo ambient" textures of her early work into a cyber-folk vignette that pierces your heart and subverts your ear. Its emotional clarity is overwhelming; the track abandons words for a climax of hymnal chords which slowly fade into a denouement of silence. Time, as it must, has run out. - Jake Indiana

items.title: Juggernaut
items.label: Kapsize
items.description: 2024 was filled to the brim with throwbacks to that foggy period in the late '00s when dubstep was being transformed. This British bass revival also meant that when Joker dropped a 140 BPM monster, he'd arguably never sounded more contemporary. "Juggernaut" is classic Joker: ethereal strings and anthemic horns twist over sparse drum programming and distorted bass so nasty it could make Howard Stern blush.What keeps "Juggernaut" from being a nostalgic victory lap is how he turns everything up to 11. He's had big drops before, but nothing as gargantuan as the lift-off a minute into "Juggernaut." This is "Tron" for a whole new generation. - Henry Ivry

items.title: Haraka حركة
items.label: Astral People
items.description: "Haraka حركة" is a monumental convergence between Moktar and Egyptian Mahraganat luminary Saad El Soghayar. Translating to "movement" in Arabic, the track is a unique and powerful meeting point of two street-born genres that embody celebration, cultural resistance and community. Moktar has weaved El Soghayar's wedding anthem into a tapestry of traditional darbuka rhythms and drum & bass, creating a rhythmically rich dialogue of tension and release.Moktar has managed to span meridians, creating a knockout that echoes the venn diagram of heritage and contemporary dance music. From Cairo's DIY block parties to London's pirate radio, "Haraka حركة" is a testament to how the underground has always spoken the same language, no matter where it calls home. - Ramsey Tawil

items.title: Nasty
items.label: Tinashe Music/Nice Life
items.description: Janet Jackson owns the word "Nasty." But you know what? The economy's rough. You can forgive her—even thank her—for leasing it out to Tinashe, who didn't take on stewardship of the word lightly.Tinashe's "Nasty" is both an impeccable Janet tribute—minimal, casual and freaky in all the right places—and a marker of what you can achieve if you tell the major label pop ecosystem to do one and chart your own path instead. It's the kind of song that seems forgettable at first listen and totally indispensable by your third, in part because it's so confident. Unlike so much pop this year, "Nasty" is so unbothered about proving itself to you that it's easy to dismiss at first glance, even as its rubbery bassline and off-kilter vocal samples build and build. Dismiss it at your peril. - Shaad D'Souza

items.title: Fawn
items.label: SPE:C
items.description: Los Angeles bass enthusiast Carré elevated her skills in the studio this year. Following stellar releases on Beatrice M.'s Bait and Fast at Work, Air Sign EP was the standout. Sandwiched between a pair of heavier bangers, its comparatively low-key B-side, "Fawn," is a masterful distillation of her signature technoid dubstep. Moving at a subtly brisker clip than traditional 140, the track's bass pulses, spiralling vocals and dubbed-out drums shift and cycle, evoking the earth-rattling march of a giant.After 80 seconds of moody table-setting, a playful series of plucks erupts seemingly from nowhere, skipping up and down in pitch. Then, as quickly as it arrived, this cute riff is gone, displaying Carré's deft control over arrangement. For anyone curious about dark and minimal dubstep's evolution over the past decade, this is the place to start. - Tom Gledhill

items.title: BYE BYE
items.label: Matador
items.description: Kim Gordon landed the coldest industrial trap record of 2024, you say? Why not. Where earlier instances of the downtown icon fringing electronic music were speckled in hiss—see Ciccone Youth's insouciant Madonna flip "Into The Groovey" or far-out noise excursions with illbient pioneer DJ Olive—"BYE BYE" is incredibly forthright.It's loud, both in the offhand banality of Kim Gordon rapping a pre-trip checklist (turtleneck, milk thistle, vibrator), as well as the collision of synth stabs, abrasive guitars and a beat that knocks like a cinder block to the head. Gordon can evidently sell anything. And if you figure the former frontwoman of Sonic Youth has no business being on an RA end-of-year list, well, I can think of two words she might use to bid that sentiment adieu too. - Gabriel Szatan

items.title: Breakthespell
items.label: R&R
items.description: If we're being honest, part of Mk.gee's appeal is that you can't understand a word he's saying. Throughout his dazzling debut album, Two Star & the Dream Police, the New Jersey-born artist's warbled vocals are at points barely decipherable—prioritising atmosphere over precision, which cloaks his music in a quixotic, almost Jai Paul-ish mist.On "Breakthespell," his voice melts into the heavily delayed guitars and billowing synths he's become known for. Once you finally manage to decode lyrics, they only heighten the hazy ambience, as he anguishedly calls out: "I can't win / And I won't end." The agent of his heartbreak is unclear; although if the song title offers any hints, it might even be Mk.gee himself. "Breakthespell" may not provide clarity, but it doesn't matter—this is the sound of catharsis. - Bella Aquilina

items.title: Morning Sun
items.label: Abantu
items.description: It was almost inevitable that Charisse C, one of the UK's leading ambassadors for amapiano, would eventually step out from behind the decks and into the vocal booth. "Morning Sun" is her bright take on the beloved genre, buoyed by airy vocals that create a sense of spiritual peace. But those sparkling notes soon transform into a moody dance floor heater, channelling the irresistible drama of amapiano and 3-step's percussive patterns.With Kwamzy on the assist, the pair created a hybrid anthem that represents the vibrant sounds of contemporary South African dance music. As well as being an excellent entry into the canon, "Morning Sun" represents Charisse C's natural progression from DJ to fully rounded artist—and she makes it look effortless. - Jesse Bernard

items.title: slob air
items.label: Hyperdub
items.description: You never know what to expect from South London composer Mica Levi. Their last solo record, 2021's Blue Alibi, was a spiky, lo-fi grunge affair, while their score for Jonathan Glazer’s 2023 chilling film The Zone of Interest unleashed nightmares through experimental found sound.This summer, Levi once again opted for unpredictability with their Hyperdub debut, the 12-minute dream pop epic hypnotically circles around a loop of undulating synths, a rumbling bass hum and an assertive, locked-in beat. Occasionally, the transcendental melody is interrupted by a slight key change or the growing swell of indecipherable voices, but it's never enough to unseat the song's steady, meditative pace. "slob air" is like watching the sun rise on the top deck of the bus after a bleary night out—life-affirming. - Steph Philips

items.title: Tubes
items.label: Thoughtforms
items.description: Uruguayan artist Fernando Zapico, AKA Z@P, has been steadily drip-feeding low-slung, acid tech house into the catalogues of niche labels for years. Now, his endeavours have culminated on Red, a statement of intent on own imprint. The EP's sharpest cut, "Tubes," features a classic proggy synth line that syphons off inspiration from techno, electro and wave, intertwining pulsing synths with metallic rhythms that pitter-patter across the four-four grid.While the rest of the EP nods towards some of the nostalgic signifiers defining today's zeitgeist—consider the mesmeric bounce of Kalahari Oyster Cult's output—"Tubes"' insatiable groove is the real winner. It's easy to imagine it ripping at the height of a raucous party, the crowd swaying to its heaving beat. - Chloe Lula

items.title: Eusexua
items.label: Young
items.description: In 2024, pop stars shaped culture not only through their art, but by outright defining social mores and public behaviour. Tinashe's "Nasty" allowed an anxiety-ridden generation having less casual sex to try on a slutty persona and Charli xcx's carefree BRAT paved a green road from the club to the Vice President's office.As the sun began to set on late summer, avant-pop visionary FKA twigs also chimed in with the sultry mystique of "Eusexua," the title track from her forthcoming album. While muted techno kicks thump in the distance, the song immediately introduces us not only to a feeling (which twigs describes as "the pinnacle of human experience"), but also an entire cinematic universe full of alien tattoos, silver statement jewellery, seven-inch Pleasers and sheer lingerie. twigs has always sung around the dance floor's periphery, but on "Eusexua," she's never sounded so sure of her place in the heart of the club. - Kiana Mickles

items.title: Diagonal (Dub Mix)
items.label: Nice & Deadly
items.description: It's almost too easy to make a club incinerator with Logan_olm on the mic. The London MC has proven time and again that his fierce flows can dominate any beat. In 2024, he met his match in São Paulo funk export RHR, who spent years observing the UK scene from almost 6,000 miles away, fusing his learnings with Brazil's diasporic rhythms. So when he finally got in the ring with Logan, what was the result?The pair's rowdy team-up, "Diagonal (Dub Mix)," vaults straight out the blocks with disorientating sample chops and a chest-caving rumble, laying the perfect foundation for the MC's righteous assertions of his own ability to storm onto any track and make himself heard. Stomping bass that slips off its axis; flecks of flanged synth; percussion that reaches for tamborzão—it's a whirlwind of energy. "Diagonal (Dub Mix)" is the sound of São Paulo and London colliding spectacularly. - Nathan Evans

items.title: flight fm
items.label: Hinge Finger
items.description: There's always one: doggedly ubiquitous, memed halfway to oblivion, the international overplayers' anthem. Our answer came in record time this year, after "flight fm" landed on January 17th and confirmed that Overmono's Dobermanns would be treated to 12 months of much needed R&R. Dance floors haven't exactly been light on wallopers cribbing their sub action from darkside jungle and speed garage lately, so to understand why "flight fm" went supernova, it's worth paying attention to what the song doesn't do."flight fm" is no-nonsense enough to make the track it might be modelled on, Si Begg's "Revolution No 1," sound positively cluttered. A dainty pre-tremor, some skippy drums and that enormous, grungy bassline—done. Incredibly effective. Vast pockets of negative space compelled others to fill in the blanks, which is why everyone from ropey TikTok remixers to Future and even The Chainsmokers (yes, seriously) mobbed in. What Joy O understands more than most is that a killer hook only represents half the battle. You still need the nous to clear everything else out the way and let it roll. - Gabriel Szatan

items.title: Waiting
items.label: Mais Um
items.description: Snakeskin's second album, They Kept Out Photographs, reflects on a tumultuous year in Lebanon, fuelled by a sense of anger, melancholy and defiance. Its pièce de résistance is the ominous and introspective "Waiting," which features one half of the duo, Julia Sabra, reciting an excerpt from Lebanese poet Etel Adnan's To Be in a Time of War. The words, profoundly poignant on their own, transform simple ongoings of daily life into acts of resistance during wartime.Paired with strong drums, the track opens with an eerie beat reminiscent of a church bell or a loud clock tolling the arrival of doomsday. The combination of Sabra's gradually distorting voice, the increasingly aggressive rhythm and almost mundane lyrics is deeply hypnotic, immersing us in Snakeskin's alternate reality. Yet, like a silver lining amid the heaviness, chimes add a subtle brightness, hinting at the resilience that quietly endures beneath the agony of living through destruction. - Tamara Saade

items.title: Ganzfeld (Djrum Remix)
items.label: Kapsela
items.description: Djrum vs. Objekt? The nerds were salivating. Djrum vs. Objekt on "Ganzfeld"? Tongues were practically on the floor. The ten-minute odyssey gets the gong for the year's glitchiest anthem, shapeshifting its way through tender piano, Syro-style turbulence and half-time freakouts with an exhilarating level of detail and unpredictability."Giving something a completely new context is, in some ways, the name of the game," Djrum recently told RA. He was talking about DJing, but you can tell he applied the same philosophy to this remix, transforming Objekt's much loved electro classic into a swarm of breakbeats and squiggly left turns. Few could have nailed it so hard. - Carlos Hawthorn

items.title: Blinkmoth (July Mix)
items.label: AD 93
items.description: This year, no artist has made downtempo more appealing than New York producer James K, whose breathy, lilting vocals have floated across some of 2024's best music. It makes sense that amid sustained geo-political violence and economic turbulence, we'd again find solace in shoegaze—music that slows the anxious heart while holding a mirror to deep-rooted angst we prefer to leave unspoken."Blinkmoth (July Mix)" commanded repeat listens this year for an instantaneous pull that sucks you into the muted vortex of James K's romantic solitude. As she sings about the endless transference of love, a trip-hop beat glides and gallops, tactfully situating us in the '90s. But really, it's the heavenly vocals that we're here for. Her delivery glistens with the Elizabeth Fraser effect: carried foremost by feeling, the curvature of her indecipherable lyrics capture the fleeting moment in which euphoria sinks into quiet melancholy. Additions like this to the electronic shoegaze revival should give any non-believer proof of its enduring relevance. - Kiana Mickles

items.title: Bikini
items.label: TraTraTrax
items.description: A great pop song is like a charm: compact and entrancing, a daydream corked and uncorked at will. If it can't guarantee good fortune, it can at least transport a listener somewhere they feel lucky to be. And no song in 2024 made as great an escape as Nick León and Erika de Casier's "Bikini.""It leaks into the music somehow," León said earlier this month of growing up by the ocean. The Miami native describes his compositions as spaces to inhabit rather than stories; a personal stamp strong enough to transform any output he lends his hand to, be that ambient (Gloria) or perreo heaters (Rompediskoteka). De Casier wields similar scene-setting skills: she wrote one of 2023's stickiest earworms, New Jeans' "Super Shy," without ever sacrificing her signature delicate style presented to perfection on 2019 breakout album, Essentials.An anthem like "Bikini" was always on the cards for the pair: their last collaboration, the Dionysian "Ex-Girlfriend" with SHYGIRL, nailed the body-first composition of Nelly Furtado and Timbaland's best work. Harp-like keyboard notes pierce the clip of a bassline, plunging into deep dembow as elegantly as four-on-the-floor. Embracing de Casier's crystalline mezzo-soprano, "Bikini" pushes sound into pure sensation: sand between toes and lips on goose-pimpled skin. When she was a teenager, "going to the swimming pool was the worst thing I could imagine," she told Mixmag in 2021. A decade-plus later, "Bikini" comes alive in the shedding of those inhibitions: why hedge around the pool, when you could head straight for the sea?Despite "Bikini"'s deft movement between shifting rhythmic patterns, the track still manages to capture a profound sense of pause. Trying to make sense of the changing tides—"Lookin' out there / Tryin' to find a meaning"—de Casier only finds herself recentered "with the wind in my hair, just breathing in the air." It's these atmospheric tendencies that take "Bikini" from the track of September to the track of the year. Before León and de Casier, artists from Otis Redding to Kelela have gazed "out there," hoping to find some sort of solace in the meeting of water and sky. And in a year so rife with misery, there are plenty of reasons to be fearful for the future. But "Bikini" charts a different course—it's a three-minute appeal to just be. - Hattie Lindert

items.title: Active Agents and House Boys
items.label: downwards
items.description: Surgeon and Regis have been creating industrial anthems as British Murder Boys for more than two decades. Individually, they're synonymous with taut, stripped back dance floor grooves that close a circle between musique concrète and steel-toed techno. But when they come together, their output is raw and unbridled, channelling the punk lineage of Coil, Suicide and Throbbing Gristle.Indeed, their debut LP, Active Agents and House Boys, is fundamentally live-sounding, its distorted kicks and walls of resonant feedback grinding like unoiled gears. Yet the music's embrace of funk and even melody — a new string to their bow—underlines the duo's conviction that serious music doesn't have to take itself so seriously. - Chloe Lula

items.title: Unearthed Vol.II*100 Trax*
items.label: self-released
items.description: 100 tunes. Let that sink in for a second. One hundred. The craziest thing? Unearthed Vol. II *100 Trax* isn't even a slog. In fact, these bitesize jams slide down like a fresh cocktail—all zinger, no filler.Regal86's exquisite drum work, crafty sampling and smoky sound palette coat the vast Bandcamp dump in a marked soulfulness. Even more impressive, he's no one-trick pony: the Monterrey producer is just as adept slinging out dubby ambient techno ("Deep Forest") and slamming hip-hop ("Quiero que sepan") as euphoric hardcore ("Fades") and the hardgroove ("Baby Phat Jacket") he built his name on. Honestly, it's all so good. All of it. - Carlos Hawthorn

items.title: Akoma
items.label: Planet Mu
items.description: The first thing Jlin fans will notice on her third album, Akoma, is that the producer and composer's idol, Philip Glass, has added his famous arpeggios. Avant-garde queen Björk and contemporary ensemble Kronos Quartet also impressively made the roster.These features hint at the direction Jlin, who has gone from inventive footwork producer to unruly experimental composer, has taken over the years. "Eye Am"'s jubilant hand drums find more common ground with traditional African drumming, whereas "Summon" creates tension with a torrent of piercing strings. Rest assured, though, one listen to the plinky keys and juddering rhythms on "Grannie's Cherry Pie" confirms that this is still music that will spring dancers and footworkers into action. - Kiana Mickles

items.title: Catching Chickens EP
items.label: Nourished By Time
items.description: Nourished by Time makes double-take music. When you first hear Marcus Brown's hypnagogic R&B anthems, you almost can't believe someone is going that hard. His songs, which gesture towards the spiritual truths underpinning quotidian tasks, are imbued with a life-or-death urgency by his stentorian baritone alone.Following 2023's breakout Erotic Probiotic 2, Catching Chickens sees Brown stretching out stylistically, exploring shoegaze guitars ("Poison-Soaked"), funhouse synth solos ("Had Ya Called") and classic nightclub crooning ("Romance in Me"). But it's the massive opener, "Hell of a Ride," that keeps us coming back. With its airy chorus, galloping beat and infectious "goodbye baby, goodbye" refrain, you can envisage Brown speeding off into yet uncharted territory. - Matt McDermott

items.title: Endlessness
items.label: Warp
items.description: It can be tough for a rising artist to follow up a spectacular album. Nala Sinephro's sublime debut, Space 1.8, mesmerised listeners in 2021 for its soul-stirring marriage of ambient and spiritual jazz. Three years later, the London-based harpist and modular synthesist returned with a second LP that dives deeper into restorative sounds.As its title implies, Endlessness feels like an infinite moment in time, suspended by languorous synth arpeggios and hushed sax runs. While some jazz fans prefer the dynamism of its predecessor, the beauty of Endlessness lies in its quietude. Sit back and soak up its ambrosial chords. - Nyshka Chandran

items.title: Fragments of Us
items.label: Graded
items.description: Midland's long-awaited debut album, Fragments of Us, is a moving document of queer heritage, from the peak of the AIDS crisis and institution of the UK's discriminatory Section 28 legislation to the utopian dreaming of artists like Stereogamus' Jonny Seymour and clubs like NYC Downlow.The record is a collection of moody and overcast downtempo songs, in which Midland's poignant yet glittering arpeggios and skittering drums commune with queer voices, past and present. But as much as it's an interrogation of the violence that has engulfed queer public life, Fragments of Us is also a celebration—just wait for those life-affirming strings on "Chapter 10." - Henry Ivry

items.title: Total Blue
items.label: Music From Memory
items.description: What do you picture when you think of the Los Angeles skyline? Maybe it's a haze of hot air, twinkling lights at night or how the city seems to stretch as far as the eye can see. It's that topography and atmosphere that Angeleno trio Total Blue wanted to replicate on their debut LP.They succeeded with gusto: the record is a gentle, meandering excursion through expansive ambient textures, New Age jazz experimentations and lush vintage melodies that recall noirish film scenes where the protagonist drives through Beverly Hills, totally unburdened by the downward pressures of life. A stunning escape. - Katie Thomas

items.title: Black Life, Red Planet
items.label: Gum Studio
items.description: gum.mp3 is that all-too-rare artist making smart music you can still go stupid to. The Baltimore-based producer and eldiaNYC crew member's latest offering, Black Life, Red Planet, is a studied yet unfussy expedition through house and jungle, woven with threads of blues, funk and trap."Knowingness" shakes the dust from a swampy blues riff; on "Deimos," a red herring flamenco loop gives way to dembow that could be played via a didgeridoo. "Believe," co-produced with Detroit juke master swoozydolphin, might be the first ambient soundbath with a breakbeat. gum.mp3 creates a common home for radical creative traditions too often siloed—it's one of the most innovative projects of the year. - Hattie Lindert

items.title: In Full Effect
items.label: Hyperdub
items.description: It's hard to believe it took this long for Tim Reaper to release a full-length album. Same goes for agenda-setting label Hyperdub, which, before In Full Effect, had never released a jungle LP. Luckily, Reaper and Naarm (Melbourne) producer Kloke linked up to do the honours, whisking different flavours of early '90s breakbeat into something that transcends the all-too-comfortable pastiche of revivalism.They masterfully reimagine what jungle's trajectory would've looked like had it gone on uninterrupted from its ragga era, with propulsive drum programming and emotional atmospherics serving as the project's anchor. Evocative and trance-inducing, In Full Effect has only solidified jungle's enduring versatility. - Emeka Okonkwo

items.title: Tyla
items.label: FAX/Epic
items.description: It all started with "Water." In 2023, South African pop powerhouse Tyla's refreshing R&B single launched her into global stardom—and even kicked off a millions-strong TikTok dance craze. This year's self-titled debut album builds on that momentum with a carefully balanced work that's as exciting as it is soulful, as assured as it is vulnerable.Infused with pop, Afrobeats and polished amapiano log drums, the LP is a potent reflection of the various global musical cultures that raised Tyla. Her thoughts on her own identity may have sparked social media discourse, but she stood firm in her truth, dog-walking doubters all the way to the GRAMMYs. - Shiba Melissa Mazaza

items.title: Sky Is The Limit
items.label: Love on the Rocks
items.description: Love On The Rocks' catalogue oozes fun and whimsy. On this ten-year compilation, PARAMIDA gathered label regulars (Massimiliano Pagliara, Fantastic Man) and newbies (Sweely, E-Talking) to curate a record capturing the label's exuberant palette of colour and feeling—think trancey synths, progressive grooves, wriggling 303s, dreamy melodies and pumping house rhythms.The frivolity is loudest in the bounce of Alex Kassian & Running Hot's closer "The Love Theme," which gleefully samples Haddaway's 1993 chart-topper "What Is Love." Toasting to a decade via a gleaming eight tracks is a confident missive. Some may say the compilation leans towards "guilty pleasure." To that, we say: there's no such thing—it's just pleasure. - Katie Thomas

items.title: ISS010
items.label: Ilian Tape
items.description: ISS010 strikes a chord with both factions of Skee Mask's fan base: the production nerds and the DJ set devotees. For the heads, it delivers his signature package of intricately layered sound design, dense percussion, and a wash of echo and reverb. But this time, the DJ devotees get their due as well. ISS010 marks a shift from Skee Mask’s breakbeat explorations to a more dance floor-focused sound, reflecting the heavily house and techno-infused energy of his current DJ sets. The seven-tracker blends syncopated rhythms with gorgeous melodies, weaving flashes of dubstep and ambient textures into rave-ready form. Grime-indebted beats on tracks like “The Bills” could as readily host an MC as send a Detroit loft party into overdrive, while “Double Standard” combines shimmering synths with propulsive drums, making it well suited for introspective home listening or peak-time club play. In a major year for Skee Mask, ISS010 was a record that engaged both body and soul. - Fahad Akinsanya

items.title: Tilda's Goat Stare
items.label: NAFF
items.description: CCL and Ciel are a natural fit. Not only because of the DJ-producer pair's enduring friendship, but their shared affinity for journeying through the psychedelic end of the rave spectrum, from proggy doof bangers to swampy downtempo.The unruly title track on their powerful joint EP lights the path to a portal filled with bass pressure and dialogue sampled from Tilda Swinton's 2002 film Teknolust (with an acid-spiked Priori remix to boot). "Goblin Mode" burrows into a subterranean network of synth gurgles and menacing hoover, while "Spiral Drive" sounds like a cyborg reaching for a higher state of consciousness. Who else could melt a feminist sci-fi film into chemistry-altering club trax? - April Clare Welsh

items.title: Letters to a Future Palestine
items.label: Umay
items.description: The first compilation on Nene H's UMAY label is a proud display of musical and political unity. Featuring an array of artists and allies from across the Palestinian and SWANA diaspora—ranging from Muskila and KETTALYNNE to Estoc and rRoxymore—Letters to a Future Palestine's 19 tracks are a collective call for solidarity.Traditional drum loops reworked for the rave ("Arish") and powerful Arabic vocal passages ("TARWIDA") build on the sense of ritual and communion, while disjointed breaks accompany eerie grime verses ("Ghrab Ilbain"), all bound by a palpable spirit of defiance. With proceeds going to Gaza's community kitchens, this moving collection of tracks transmits hope for Palestinian freedom. - Nyshka Chandran

items.title: Breathe, Godspeed
items.label: Timedance
items.description: On Breathe, Godspeed, Verraco is in full-throttle mode. The Colombian producer's subversive attitude takes flight via a bricolage of techno, dembow, IDM and glitch, bodying listeners with its sheer weight. Intensity levels escalate to a peak with a clever emphasis on rave fundamentals rather than shock value: there are nasty basslines, tribal influences, elements of rowdy post-dubstep and distorted vocal samples.Tracks are thunderous and jaw-dropping but strategically calibrated, transforming the cadence of Latin rhythms into a throbbing mass of futuristic sound design. Breathe, Godspeed is a radical snapshot of Verraco's music-making philosophy—it disorients, stimulates and, best of all, knows exactly what it wants to say. - Nyshka Chandran

items.title: Sentir Que No Sabes
items.label: Unheard of Hope
items.description: "At the moment, I'm pro-confusion. Or maybe not," wrote Guatemalan composer Mabe Fratti in the liner notes of her fourth LP, Sentir Que No Sabes, which means "to feel that I don't know" in Spanish. The first clue that demonstrates the strength of her latest work is opener, "Kravitz," with its funky cello bassline, dark atmospherics and strolling-pace rhythm. It's a fitting introduction to the musician's most accessible album yet, which largely forgoes the murky timbres and synth abstraction of her earlier works.Instead, tracks such as "Oídos," where Fratti's sweet soprano springs above whining trumpet, have spawned comparisons to the jazzy angst of singer-songwriters like Fiona Apple. Or take "Descubrimos un suspiro," where her voice is raw and up close as strings rustle against warm horns. On Sentir Que No Sabes, Fratti takes the threads of her denser projects and weaves it into a richly textured, utterly enthralling tapestry. - Kiana Mickles

items.title: Estradas
items.label: Latency
items.description: Nídia and Valentina Magaletti may be from different musical backgrounds, but one thing they have in common is a shared disregard for convention. Nídia is something of an outlier within the Príncipe universe, her singular brand of kuduro and batida positioned slightly outside of the label's core sound. As for Magaletti, the experimental percussionist appears to be driven by a burning desire to constantly break new rhythmic ground, with each of her collaborative projects more ambitious than the last.It's no surprise, then, that their debut joint project, Estradas, sounded like little else this year. The nine-track LP begins as a tense to and fro between two artists feeling each other out, but the moments in which they find a shared musical language are dizzying. It's both a testament to the transcendental powers of rhythm and the thrilling possibilities of improvised collaboration. - Michael Lawson

items.title: Black Eye
items.label: Bubble Tease Comms
items.description: "Fried Ice Cream Is a Reality." Maurice Fulton's Twitter bio offers a glimpse into a typically press-shy artist's delight for oddball concepts. The Baltimore DJ and producer's vast discography connects the dots between disco, jazz, house and experimental electronics, from BOOF and Eddie & The Eggs to unexpected collaborations with Crystal Waters and Roísin Murphy.His singular sense for fusing the weird and the funky has perhaps never been more apparent than on Syclops' fourth album, Black Eye. The trio—Fulton, percussionist Mim Suleiman and guitarist Hanna Sarkari—delivers yet another kaleidoscopic album bursting at the seams with ideas: tracks like "Pink Sarah NYC Is Back" invoke future jazz and bleep techno, while "Karo Is Going Swimming" sounds like dub techno chucked through a cosmic blender. It's frankly bananas, and our dance floors are all the better for it. - Bella Aquilina

items.title: These Heavens
items.label: XL Recordings
items.description: When getting arms around this riot of hyper-technical programming, overlapping rivulets of sound and intricate fidelity, it's worth stating things plainly: These Heavens is one of the most satisfying EPs in quite some time.Drum & bass virtuoso gyrofield (AKA Kiana Li) has been quietly prolific in recent years, popping up everywhere from Critical to Eastern Margins. Yet it was her XL debut where she truly shot for the moon with a record informed by stargazing and Stephen Hawking as much as Hideo Kojima and Noisia. Li practically undergoes a full villain arc in 23 minutes, staging a shift from tones so crystalline you'd be forgiven for thinking they were beamed direct from the Pillars of Creation, to mottled drumfunk hissing and heaving under the weight of menace. These Heavens is explosive, but more than that, it's pure cosmology in motion. - Gabriel Szatan

items.title: Queridão
items.label: Nyege Nyege Tapes
items.description: DJ Anderson do Paraíso knows how to twist baile funk's frenetic energy into haunted minimalism. The Belo Horizonte native's productions merge sparse electronic elements inspired by drill and trap with sluggish violins, pianos, flutes and timpani—all of which fill the air with a mysterious sensuality and ominous aura. Queridão, which translates to "beloved" from Portuguese, is a collection of tracks that has taken the producer from SoundCloud cult favourite to living legend in the rising funk mineiro scene of Belo Horizonte.The mountainous, landlocked city is widely celebrated for its slower and more melodic take on funk, but what sets Anderson apart is his commitment to downright eerie experimentalism, stripping down the sound's full-bodied elements to forge epic and radical restraint. It's really no wonder that Queridão stands out as some of the most enticingly abstract dance music of the year. - GG Albuquerque

items.title: Da Nao Tian Gong
items.label: Midgar
items.description: Da Nao Tian Gong is Polygonia's most watched childhood film. Translating to "Havoc in Heaven," the narrative links heaven to nature—from the peaches of immortality in the Heavenly Garden to Fruit Mountain. The Chinese-German artist has consistently sought out lessons from our environment, recently telling Resident Advisor: "People should collaborate together in peace to save our planet."In 2024, Earth is increasingly heating up. Cities—and people—have been set alight. On Da Nao Tian Gong, Polygonia makes sense of this destruction through an effervescent mix of ambient, techno and downtempo, using the synthetic to recreate the organic, from a synth pad dawn chorus to the rhythmic hissing of water. Nestled at the heart of this sublime EP lies the simple yet powerful message of protecting our world. The peaches, the seeds, the roots. In a year of mass displacement, what could be more pertinent than that? - Vivian Yeung

items.title: Great Doubt
items.label: Escho
items.description: Great Doubt is Astrid Sonne's first album as a singer-songwriter, but she's been using her voice for much longer. The Danish artist has spoken about her time spent in church choirs, acknowledging its role in shaping her vocals: "I definitely wouldn't be singing as loud as I do." On Great Doubt, Sonne is definitely loud, producing immense emotional volume out of sparse arrangements."Do you wanna" arrives with a straight but heavy drum beat as Sonne confesses, "Do you wanna have a baby? / I really don't know." This unnervingly direct existentialism runs through the entire album, whether in the slow, booming 808s on "Everything is unreal" or the simple pizzicato viola on "Almost." Sonne doesn't shy away from bold, unembellished statements, only augmenting the sense of intimacy (as on the plaintive, Ben Vince-assisted "Say you love me"). In daring to confront her deepest fears head-on, Sonne has made the year's most striking pop album. - Bella Aquilina

items.title: BRAT
items.label: Atlantic
items.description: For a decade, Charli xcx thrashed between two seemingly contradictory stations: pop sweetheart and cult icon. She lacquered finely tuned singles in industry-standard polish, then loaded brilliant, labyrinthine albums with dense lines about her deepest fears. With BRAT, she swung to please her niche—and ended up painting the summer radioactive green. Her most momentous album to date is a rare animal: a galvanising pop record all wound up for the club on one hand, a glistening smorgasbord of spilled guts on the other.By turning her insecurities inside out on songs like "Sympathy is a knife" and "Girl, so confusing," then counterweighting those cerebations with the whole-body release of "Von dutch" and "Club classics," Charli alchemised a new vision of her own success. She's long picked over the question of what it means to make it. BRAT homes in on something of an answer: there's no "it" to make. Sell all the records you want, or don't—you have to come home to yourself either way. Might as well crank the bass and dance through it. - Sasha Geffen

items.title: Bubbling Forever
items.label: Nyege Nyege Tapes
items.description: Slamming body music from a true master who transmits the vivacity and nerve of Caribbean club culture: that's Bubbling Forever. On his second official collection of bubbling—a sped-up mutation of dancehall—Dutch-Surinamese producer De Schuurman builds on the genre's Afro-diasporic legacy with a clutch of tracks designed to whip up hysteria in the rave."Benniale Dakar" starts with the ominous drama of an early Pop Smoke trap tune then launches into a rattling speed dembow. As smoky pads permeate the air, the beat decelerates into half-time—only a quick moment to gather your waist before the wine-inducing rhythms of "Bubbling Meets Kaseko," which fuse bubbling's restless kicks with traditional Surinamese skratji percussion. On "Stylez two," mischievous samples of Lil Jon's infamous "OK!" and KRS-One's "Sound of da Police" can jolt even the stiffest hips into work. When "Scratchin"'s pointillist synths plink around vocal samples of "I'm just scratchin' the surface," you get the sense it's both a call to action and warning shot: Schuurman is here to stay. - Rachel Grace Almeida

items.title: One Day
items.label: Incienso
items.description: Not waving, or drowning, but drifting. That's how 2024 felt for many of us: a serotonin crash made all the more raw by an increasingly cruel world. After years of clubland electrifying the masses with the shock of the new, we chose to lean the other way, prioritising cosy records that made you thankful for what you already have (a craving that, in alternative circles, drew people to the spectral-jukebox transmissions of Cindy Lee like moth to flame). Into this climate landed a masterclass in softer vibrations from Brian Leeds, who, as Huerco S. and Pendant, has already proved himself a master of suspended animation several times over. One Day both encapsulated the mood and cut through it like a beacon.Does it augur poorly for a culture built on progression to take a step back and recalibrate? Well, the past was priced in; Loidis is the ancient name for Leeds, after all. And though One Day was built around slippery micro rhythms and delayed dub stabs, Leeds hardly soapboxed for a return to subtlety. The strongest promo was essentially happenstance, after he termed the project "dub mnml emo tech" to wriggle out of anything too formal, but wound up perfectly articulating its playful vibe.Just as For Those Of You…'s truncated loops were a creative sleight-of-hand, One Day pulls off a sly trick throughout.
