Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Looking For Trouble
items.description:
In just a few years, Mall Grab went from master of a niche to king of everything. His debut album is a Chemical Brothers-sized crossover behemoth, attacking every form of radio-friendly dance music, from big room house to pounding jungle. It's inspired by the sounds of his adopted home of London, and to his credit, it captures what makes the city so enduring in dance music history. A restless blend of sound system culture, American and European imports and the kind of vocal hooks you hear on BBC Radio 1—with a few vocal turns from the man himself—it transforms Mall Grab from bedroom producer into something closer to a pop star. -A.R.




Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Leisure System
items.description:
Gerald Donald and To-Nhan Le Thi of Dopplerekkeft's second LP, like many 2022 albums, emerged from the toils of pandemic-induced isolation. The album's accompanying press text loftily asserts that its ten tracks are "considerations of the machine-human interface" and "transformative mental, psychological and transgenerational states." While some of these (perhaps overwrought) academic themes come through in the album's titles, it mostly sounds like the duo's mood piece-like electro fare—in the best possible way. The tracks throughout Neurotelepathy aren't predictable arrangements made for club play. They're spare and considered, making exquisite use of spatial sound design, spectral percussion and arpeggiated melodies. Some songs, like "EEG," take more than a minute to settle into a more legible song structure, but their expertly rendered craftsmanship make them worth the wait. -C.L.




Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Hyperdub
items.description:
Spoken word and darbuka drums join in holy matrimony on this joint album from 700 Bliss—Philadelphia-based Moor Mother and DJ Haram. As the first full-length work from the duo after a series of collaborative EPs, Nothing To Declare sees the two artists claiming their matriarchal stake in electronic music. Haram's frenetic electronics speak in dialogue with Moor Mother's throaty vocals, delivered with a potent urgency. "Things ain't been the same since they put the lynch on us / water thicker than blood they convinced us," Ayewa opines. She's always been fearless in her delivery, but it's Muzeyyen's jagged productions that drive the point home. -W.W.




Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: SVBKVLT
items.description:
SVBKVLT became one of the most important club music labels by showcasing the vital Shanghai club scene, though the label's purview has expanded and only become more vibrant in the process. Case in point: this LP from Cairo producer ABADIR, which combines a freewheeling style of jungle with Arabic rhythms. This is music that sounds permanently out of breath, feeding off its own excitable energy. Inspired by maqsoum music and the humid bustle of the Egyptian capital, Mutate features impossibly funky beats shrouded in thick field recordings and melodies that hang in the air like smog. It's a vision of the kind of global club music that SVBKVLT has always championed, and one of the best records in a catalogue that constantly ups the ante for where club music can go next. -A.R.




Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Timedance
items.description:
According to the International Gem Society, an opal is "distinctly individual"—more so than any other gemstone. The 3D-rendered opal on the cover of Batu's debut album is just that: a unique kaleidoscope of colours. Icy blue, vibrant green and a hot, lava red contrast with the grey underside of the opal and the moody background. Examining Opal's cover gives a strong sense of the sounds within. 11 tracks of sharp (though sometimes soft), complex and unpredictable electronic sculptures, a world of intricate sound design that Batu said he intended to feel vivid and transportive. Like so many LPs released this year, Opal is a lockdown record, made when Batu was in an introspective and contemplative state of mind, experimenting with moving away from club 12-inches and into a space more vulnerable and experimental. -K.T.




Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Young
items.description:
Caprisongs was one of the first RA Recommends of the year, and it was no surprise to many of us that it lingered long enough in our minds to make this end of year list. The album is brighter than anything we'd heard from twigs before. Gone is the operatic austerity of MAGDALENE. Instead, Caprisongs  is a pop album with a capital P. The album mines from Afrobeats, grime, baile funk and R&B. It also sources from her personal life via snippets of conversations she recorded with loved ones. The immersive world she creates here deals with insecurity, "stupid boys" and friendship, but it's also celebratory. The world had opened up, after all. Twigs might have had a cry now and then, but at least she was doing it on the dance floor in the album's first single, "Tears In The Club.". As phenomenal as Caprisongs is, it's somehow even more impressive because it was pulled off with a welcome sense of humour. The album title, for example, is inspired by astrology—her "stubborn Caprisun ass telling her to work through the pain." Listeners can even eavesdrop on an astrological reading by the album's close. Sometimes, a little stubbornness is worth it. -K.M.




Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Theo Parrish
items.description:
"There are no genres. Nope, there's none. It's all tune for tune," Theo Parrish said outside the familiar NTS stall in Dalston's Gillett Square. And he doesn't just talk to talk. Many DJs claim to play across genres, but there are "many DJs" and then there is Theo Parrish. Over the past few years, the historically private artist has given fans a near-unprecedented view into his creative mind, first with the lengthy and unclassifiable sonic essay-meets-radio drama We Are All Georgeous Monsterss, and then this year with a six-and-a-half hour mix for NTS called "Eargoggles." (Parrish also dropped another six-hour mix close to press time.) 

Eargoggles is a marathon celebration of the infinite diversity of Black music, spanning from hard bop to hip-hop, searing psych rock to roots reggae. No random grab bag, this is a grand narrative and the revelation of a modern canon of soul with appearances by James Brown, The Congos and D'Angelo. The mix is an education unto itself—around hour five Parrish drops "Jazz Cats Part 1," a cut consisting of Madlib breathlessly laying out his key jazz influences—yet it's also a generous statement of purpose bursting with joy and urgency.

25 years into his career, Parrish gives us an exhaustive guide to the music that makes him tick, that has informed his own enduring classics. But why now? He explains the gravity of his convictions in the final moment of the magisterial "Eargoggles" mix:

I'm hoping that at some point during this... After you've had a ride, a musical ride with me, that you take a moment to consider the troubles that you have, and consider that you're lucky to have them.

Even if it doesn't affect you demographically, you should seriously consider the fact that there's an urgency that should be lived, in respect for those that get taken from us early under the guise of 'serve and protect.'

So let's survive together. But let's remember them together as well. Let's not forget how we treat each other when the music's playing and how things change when the lights go on and we all go back to the rest of our lives.

Let's go back with a little more urgency and care for the fellow man. Let's give a damn a little bit. And if we can do that, we got a better place.—Matt McDermott

items.label: Tim Sweeney
items.description: Over the past 21 years, Tim Sweeney never missed a week on the WNYU airwaves, hosting generations of DJs in the college station's basement studios. Beats In Space became iconic over this decades-long stretch, with Sweeney joining a grand tradition of New York radio DJs that also includes Shep Pettibone, Tony Humphries, Stretch and Bobbito, who held sway and influence far beyond the five boroughs. Though Sweeney has since brought Beats In Space back via Apple Music, last March he unexpectedly wrapped up his term on WNYU with episode #1085. Listeners flooded the comment section on a YouTube livestream after the news broke, thanking him for his illustrious tenure. For the finale, Sweeney played Beats In Space classics that highlighted the show's connection to the history of New York City dance music, dropping in an eclectic selection from Alicia Myers, Chaz Jankel and Arnold Jarvis. Full of hope, the two-and-a-half hours imparts a heartfelt message of gratitude to dedicated listeners and guests alike.—M.M.

items.label: Crystallmess
items.description: We're in the age of the polymath musician, and Crystallmess is the epitome. The French-born Ivorian and Guadeloupean DJ, producer and mixed media artist (who has shown her work at the Centre Pompidou and the Geneva Biennale, as well as playing at hallowed institutions like Berghain), has steadily made her way into the art and electronic music vanguards simultaneously. For her entry in the Borshch Magazine series, Crystallmess uses the mix format to express the social whiplash of lockdowns and reopenings, all the while showing off her agile genre-agnosticism. She includes edits of beloved Lil Wayne and Aaliyah tracks, blown-out jungle sampling "Ready or Not" by The Fugees, swirled with a heavy-handed dose of otherworldly ambient to evoke the expansive solitude of pandemic isolation.—Whitney Wei

items.label: Irini
items.description: Lost In Dreams was another entry in the growing SoundCloud archive of Traumprinz's resplendent multiverse. Irini, one of the elusive artist's many pseudonyms, trots out over three hours worth of new material, charting a comprehensive course in sensitive dance music from someone who creates at a relentless pace. Unlike some of his other aliases, irini doesn't have a unique sound in the way that DJ Healer or the Prince Of Denmark do, but that's also what makes this mix so rewarding. The dub techno, UK garage, even minimal house productions spring forth from an enigmatic source, keeping the intrigue of listening alive. Now it's just a matter of waiting for the inevitable vinyl releases.—Henry Ivry

items.label: Wata Igarashi
items.description: A live set from techno's undisputed master of arpeggios, Wata Igarashi, is a special thing no matter where it takes place: dark basements or—why not—the Nobeyama Radio Observatory. Located in Yatsugatake, Japan, the observatory has been a hub for radio astronomy research since 1982. Its imposing rows of satellites and telescopes, set against a beautiful landscape, provide an almost too-good-to-be-true backdrop for Igarashi's cosmic, otherworldly sound. Beautifully shot on video by ETCHED (an audiovisual project showcasing domestic artists), the set plunges into the outer reaches of Igarashi's unmistakable productions, reworking previous records and some unreleased material into an hour-long trip that remains one of 2021's most memorable techno sets.—Richard Akingbehin

items.label: OSSX
items.description: For many of us, New Jersey group OSSX's "Split Wig" on Allergy Season was one of the year's indisputable anthems. And the only thing better than just one track is a whole hour of exclusive material. 100% UNRELEASED OSSX is a goldmine for anyone into big drums and even bigger melodies (with a "Split Wig" appearance early on). There's a light-footed touch to breakbeats, plus some nimble choppage and a parade of brazen, uplifting edits that sample a tongue-in-cheek gamut: Modjo to Janet Jackson to September's Eurodance hit "Cry For You." It's that "Are they really doing this? Sampling that?" swagger that cinches this mix as one of our endlessly replayable favorites this past year.—Andrew Ryce

items.label: Josey Rebelle
items.description: Josey Rebelle could—and probably will, honestly—make this list every year for the foreseeable future, and it would be nothing short of deserved. The UK DJ is one of the best selectors on the planet, with a record digger's taste but a party-rocker's ear. She'll play obscure records, sure, but they'll never feel obscure. Her mix, first released as a very limited tape on The Trilogy Tapes in April, is a perfect example of this, stitching together slow jams, weirdo techno and even snippets of radio play, with a darker edge than what we're used to from some of Rebelle's recent mixes. The eventual streaming upload of the mix was greeted with the fervor of an album drop, and for good reason: this TTT Mix strums the eclectic but intuitive thread that’s tied through all of her sets. The only flaw is that it isn't twice as long.—A.R.

items.label: DESYN
items.description: In certain circles, the name Desyn Masielo commands a kind of reverence, and the London lifer has been blending the finest never-on-YouTube Discogs gems for the past two decades. Here, Masiello flaunts those deep-digging DJ tendencies with wild abandon. Ghostcast14, recorded live at Hoppetosse, is a good intro to what he can achieve when he goes for the jugular from the very beginning. We start in medias res with UK garage basslines, but his masterful pacing and mixing means that before we know it, we're zipping through starry rave, acidic electro, '90s house and just about everything else under the sun. For us mortal trainspotters, the only thing worse than having missed this party is that we'll likely never know what any of these records are.—H.I.

items.label: DJ Fart In The Club
items.description: DJ Fart In The Club (AKA Soyoon Choi) certainly has an offbeat sense of humor, but when it comes to their DJ sets, they're entirely straight-faced. Even though this set came in at the tail end of last year, it still banged all the way through into 2021. The Berlin artist unleashes a sticky hour-and-a-half of acid-tinged wobblers, prog house and freaky trance for the Chicago-based, women and non-binary focused podcast series Daisychain. In the knottier sections, Choi takes listeners on a jaunt full of vertiginous peaks and deep valleys by roving into spiraling wormholes of techno, garage and preternatural club music.—Kiana Mickles

items.label: CCL
items.description: In the weeds of the first 20 minutes of CCL's sit on my interface mix, it's easy to presume that this is a fully ambient offering. But that would be a hasty judgement, as once it approaches the one-hour mark, the energy intensifies with such careful, gradual restraint that even the active listener might wonder how they even got to this point. Sure enough, the mix ultimately reaches a dark, slinky plateau with a bubbling, percussive roller and then rockets off from there. "sit on my interface (2/2)" can't arrive soon enough.—K.M.

items.label: Poly Kicks
items.description:
2021 felt like Overmono's breakthrough year. Each new release of theirs seemed to outdo the last, from the euphoric rave of "Pieces Of 8" to their pitch-perfect fabric mix to the peppy garage of "Diamond Cut" (one of the major highlights from what was arguably the year's best Essential Mix). But it was "So U Kno," released not on the duo's usual home of XL Recordings but on their own, smaller Poly Kicks imprint, that made it into what felt like every DJ set of the post-reopening world.

Like so much of Overmono's recent work, there's a whiff of a bygone, post-dubstep era to "So U Know." Built around an unforgettable vocal chop, "So U Kno" is the kind of track that elicits cheers from a dance floor the minute the DJ starts to mix it in. It has one of those in-between beats—kind of house, kind of 2-step, kind of techno—and a thrill-ride of a breakdown. Encapsulating the frenzied, overjoyed vibe of the summer's post-reopening clubbing with a hint of wistful nostalgia, "So U Kno" perfectly sums up this year's excitement and radical ups and downs.—Andrew Ryce


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Interscope Records
items.description:
Hidden in the middle of Billie Eilish's intimate, often confessional singer-songwriter album is one of the year's biggest, loudest club tracks: the pop megastar's equivalent of Nine Inch Nails' "Closer." "Cause I like to do things God wouldn't approve of / If she saw us," Eilish whispers over a clanging, outsized beat. "Oxytocin" takes the tactile, goosebump-inducing approach of Eilish's other records and blows it up to a macro scale. It's the sound of being cornered in the club, pushed towards the speaker until all you can hear are the kick drums.—A.R.

Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Regraded
items.description:
Throw a jacking house rhythm underneath the right vocal and soaring strings, and you've found yourself a tried and true way to excite a dance floor. There is nothing radical or even innovative about Elvin T's "Get Close," which hews closely to this time-honored formula, but there doesn't need to be. The Philadelphia producer laced together the perfect combination of driving percussion, vocals, a glossy string loop and a couple of breakdowns. Released as the final record on Midland's Regraded label at the start of summer, the track's timing was also fortuitous as dance floors got busier over the summer. —Henry Ivry

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Parlophone
items.description:
TikTok made PinkPantheress one of the year's defining pop stars. She became a musical sensation just for releasing snippets of songs on the video app before the full versions appeared on streaming services. Anyone who hadn't heard of PinkPantheress probably did when she finally released the music video for "Just for me," an early '00s-inspired visual depicting her on a studio stage with a sulky crew of emo kids. The Mura Masa co-produced track nodded to garage and early '00s pop-rock, perfectly encapsulating "new nostalgic," a term PinkPantheress uses to describe her own sound. If the lyrics—which follow a stalker's infatuation with a crush—are unsettling, it's intentional. The song was inspired by the obsessive themes that run through Eminem's "Stan," and is more a practice in dramatic storytelling than a portrayal of real-life events. Much like the rest of her catalog, which is tailor-made for bright-eyed Gen Z TikTokers with short attention spans and a love for danceable, snappy hooks, "Just for me" hovers around two minutes in length—just long enough to make you want to press rewind and hear it all over again.—Kiana Mickles

Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Planetary Assault Systems - Say It Loud
items.label: Token
items.description:
As Planetary Assault Systems, Luke Slater makes huge, no-bullshit techno. There's plenty of technical wizardry going on, sure, but you know what to expect: thunderdome kick drums and synths that sound like sonar pings. Enter "Say It Loud," the highlight from Belgian label Token's 100th release, which subverts Slater's historical output with a goofy sound that matches its goofy title (right down to the deadpan vocal repeating "say it loud"). Refreshing and zippy, it sounds a bit like Slater poking fun at the current crop of big-time techno producers, then beating them at their own game with a track that's over-the-top, funky and absolutely monstrous.—A.R.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Soundcloud / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: secondnature
items.description:
tondiue's debut packed an album's worth of ideas into an EP of techno that explores the outer reaches of the genre, specifically slowed-down breakbeats and tunneling, Wata Igarashi-style arpeggio workouts. "Painted Creature" falls somewhere between these styles. What starts out as a loose hand percussion workout laced with clipped, unnerving vocal samples before the breakdown turns it into a tripped-out big room techno cut that could stand up with the best of 'em. It's just one of many highlights on a techno EP that sticks with us like few others have this year.—A.R.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: HIJINXX
items.description:
Drum & bass was all over pop and R&B this year, though it rarely sounded as heavy and convincing as it did on Nia Archives' Headz Gone West, where the London singer peppers expert breakbeat chop-ups with jazzy vocal runs. The title track is an easy highlight, packing a whole lot into just over two minutes as Nia Archives sings about her anxiety, her wandering mind and getting "high just to pass the time" over beats that crest and wane like lashing ocean waves.—A.R.

Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify / SoundCloud

items.label: Klockworks
items.description:
Like his first EP for Ben Klock's label in 2019, Greek born, Kyiv-based producer Stef Mendesidis' Klockworks 33 delivered four irresistibly catchy, full-pelt techno tracks when it came out in October. "Stalker" is by far the most elegant cut of the batch, threading delicate hats and a single, sonorous pad in and out of an arpeggiated bassline that opens and closes over the course of five-and-a-half minutes. Like Klock, Mendesidis has mastered the art of functional peak-time techno that feels anthemic despite its simplicity.—Chloe Lula

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Therapy
items.description:
Logic1000's "I Won't Forget" had unfortunate timing, landing at the very beginning of the year when most of the world was still shut down. It has all the makings of a festival hit with its deliciously heavy slo-mo breakbeat and moody synths that come in halfway through the track, like tears blurring your peripheral version. Just when you think you have the track pegged down, everything falls away to reveal a truly evil-sounding Reese bassline that pushes it to another level. In all, it's a wonderful, canny fusion of UK dance music styles from a talented Australian producer.—A.R.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: PLZ Make It Ruins
items.description:
"If Anything" producer and Frank Ocean collaborator Vegyn originally found John Glacier's music on SoundCloud, but the London-based artists quickly realized they'd met before, gravitating towards each other to chat at the back of parties. It's appropriate, then, that "If Anything," the opening salvo from Glacier's debut album, brims with the swooning disorientation of a big night out. Over a triumphant, boom bap-influenced beat, Glacier raps in impressionistic turns of phrase: "Starlight, dancin' in the moon / I'm ravin' rabbit, I'm on shroom." "If Anything" introduces a visionary and arty MC with an instantly recognizable banger.—Matt McDermott

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Black Acre
items.description:
Karen Nyame KG earned the nickname "The Goddess of Rhythm" for her intricate UK funky productions, but the British-Ghanaian artist's biggest track to date came when she stepped up to the mic. "Koko" was an immediate summer hit that benefited from a magpie's approach to recent African dance music innovations. In just under three minutes, Nyame mixes airy highlife guitar, Afrobeats and amapiano. Her vocal, meanwhile, is unapologetically carnal: "Don't waste my time / I wanna bust down, bust down / Go rounds, go rounds / lights out, lights out." Modern dance music often feels like it's designed for some airless dungeon. By comparison, "Koko" feels like sex on the beach.—M.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Young
items.description:
It's safe to say the Welsh producer Koreless got a little in his head while working on his debut album, which was almost a decade in the making. The time enabled him to do endless revisions and embark on creative soul-searching that eventually paid off. The LP's ten tracks display extraordinary sonic detail and inventiveness. "Joy Squad" sticks out as a granular reimagining of a big room anthem. Chopped-up shards of melody and vocals combine with cinematic strings in a kaleidoscopic funhouse of a track that would be overwhelming if it wasn't so concise.—M.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: AD 93
items.description:
Turn Of Phrase reveals Maxwell Sterling as a rare talent, remarkably adept in both electronic sound design and orchestral arrangement. While the title track flabbergasts with a mix of furious classical runs and Autechre-level sound processing, the brief "Decay Time" is the record's centrepiece. While the drums clearly hearken back to IDM's '90s heyday, the track's plinking synth bass and strings converge to evoke a sense of deep lament. This difficult balance of head-spinning programming and lilting emotionality recalls classics within the genre like Aphex Twin's "Flim."—M.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / SoundCloud

items.text: DJ Black Low & Kapzela feat. Licy Jay & MLG - Emonate Oe Bethela D Vosho
items.label: Awesome Tapes From Africa
items.description:
Considering house and techno are inventions of the African diaspora, it feels like poetic justice that some of the most innovative changes happening in modern electronic music are emerging from the continent. In recent years, amapiano's log drum grooves have sprung from Gauteng townships to clubs around the world. DJ Black Low, the 20-year-old amapiano producer signed to Awesome Tapes From Africa, brought an experimental edge to the young genre on his 2021 album, Uwami. On "Emonate Oe Bethela D Vosho," Black Low works with Kapzela and the MCs Licy Jay & MLG to forge a groove that's as urgent as it is inviting.—M.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Exit Records
items.description:
Photek's 1997 hit "Modus Operandi" brought together the best parts of trip-hop, jazz, jungle and hip-hop. Consisting mostly of drums and atmospheric effects, it redefined drum & bass and celebrated the art of percussion itself. On his entirely improvised tribute to the track, Rajeev Maddela pulled from Photek's beat science, fusing recreated '90s breakbeats with live drumming and his own signature sound. Maddela's razor-sharp instrumentation—accentuated by ghostly pads—brought new depths to jazzy drum & bass this year.—Nyshka Chandran

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Self-released
items.description:
Only recently exiting his teenage years, rising techno prodigy Max Watts has released some of the freshest renditions of Detroit techno this year. His self-described "post-Detroit" style is unique for its raw, improvisational flow, channeling the freewheeling energy of Midwestern techno greats like Underground Resistance, Claude Young and DJ Rush. Watts's sincere investment in the emotion and groove behind his music makes way for some of the purest and most exuberant modern techno around. One of the hits off April's MW002 EP, "Hipnautic," was a favorite for its lurching percussion, drunken, loopy melody and dissipating hi-hats. Watts knows how to build and retract momentum in all the right places.—K.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Self-released
items.description:
The "Ha" stab, a rousing "crash" sample that typically falls on the 4, is to ballroom music as vocal chops are to Jersey club. They're classic hallmarks of the genres—once you hear them, it's difficult to mistake what you're listening to. The key elements of ballroom music, a style intrinsically tied to its dance culture, have understandably caught the eye of numerous club producers in recent years. And Bapari, a Brooklyn-based artist whose music draws from all manner of East Coast club styles, is one of the latest to be inspired. On the title track of their Daybreak EP, the "Ha" stab, rather than assuming its traditional role of accentuating the melody, becomes the melody across a frenzy of playful, whip-sawing crashes. Offering some respite, Bapari skillfully tempered the track with plenty of space and the occasional murmuring vocal that floats off into the ether.—K.M.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Scuffed Recordings
items.description:
There are a few simple but essential ingredients needed to make the perfect Ayesha track: nimble percussion, intoxicatingly psychedelic melodies and plenty of focus on the low-end. "Potential Energy" nails all three. The first gobsmacking moment arrives with synths that ripple with the intensity of an ultraviolet wave. Then the first acid lead slithers in, a portent of the brilliance to come: a rip-roaring showcase of lumbering breakbeats and off-kilter synths, replete with Saturday morning cartoon sound effects. It's a certified energy-boosting weapon for DJs on the late-late shift.—K.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Self-released
items.description:
Breakout artist A.G not only has a penchant for creating robust, propulsive sounds, but she's got the bravura to back it up. Last year, the East London native postedMixmag's review of her August Discwoman selections, including the tongue-in-cheek caption "heavy-bodied means I'm thick." It's quips like these—and all the offerings on her donotdisturb EP—that shirk the stereotype of the introverted bedroom producer. In standout track "always, you," A.G demonstrates a magisterial command of UK drill, directing staccato hi-hats and pitched-up vocal samples to clamber over heavy bass uppercuts with a tenacity that matches her personality. When they say "confidence is everything," take this example as a case in point.—Whitney Wei   

Listen:
Bandcamp / Spotify

items.label: Local Action
items.description:
When Jersey club royalty holds court, the world pays attention. Cherise Gray, otherwise known as UNIIQU3, has been championing the 135 BPM club music of her Newark home on the international stage for the better part of a decade, and this year she really came into her own. "Microdosing," the lead single off her Heartbeats EP, delves into house, rap and four-to-the-floor big room beats: "Took a tab and tripped / Drown in it / Fall into my abyss / The sticky icky wet wet." Gray details a lysergic wet dream that climaxes at peak time on the dance floor. Synth-heavy and oozing with confidence, the track holds the hip-swinging sashay of a lip glossed, sugar-coated seduction—without the predictable box spring squeaks.—W.W.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
"Under Belly" has a little bit of everything that we've come to love about Jamie Roberts (AKA Blawan), from his early Hessle Audio days to his tech-wiz modular techno era. It also perfectly captures what has always been refreshing about his music: He never takes himself too seriously. With its groovy swing and ghost choir motif, "Under Belly" sounds like the most fun he's ever had on record. By looking back to his early days as an honorary post-dubstep protege, Roberts proves he can return to the past while still firmly developing his sound.—H.I.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Anz - Unravel In The Designated Zone
items.label: OTMI
items.description:
Anz broke out in 2020, but her career has taken off in 2021. Between her yearly all-originals mixes and an increasingly hectic DJing and radio schedule, the Manchester artist knocked out two of the year's most exciting celebrations of UK club music. While her Ninja Tune debut All Hours was a masterclass in fusing pop with electro, UK garage and jungle, "Unravel In The Designated Zone" remains the year's high water mark. It's a bit more understated, but it still feels  like an instant classic from the moment the song's lead synth begins howling over her signature off-kilter percussion.—H.I.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / SoundCloud

items.label: All Centre
items.description:
There was plenty of genre-bending club music released this year, but Zambia-based SHE Spells Doom's release for All Centre was a hybrid like no other. The  three-track EP showcased an  impressive repertoire, crossing from UK funky to Afro house. But it was the confident swagger of "Rudnick" that kept clocking up the re-listens. The track's synth work has the technicolor polish of contemporary UK techno set over the stuttering swagger of '00s hip-hop percussion. Named for the sci-fi Oedipus anti-hero in the movie Heavy Metal, the track surpasses its namesake, creating a sense of noirish anxiety without losing sight of the funk.—H.I.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Isla
items.description:
2021 saw a new sound emanating from Canada's dance music underground led by labels like Planet Euphorique, Isla and Acting Press. No one captured this better than Maara and her sexually charged, trance-flecked take on techno and electro. Across two breakout EPs, there was a je ne sais quoi to the Montreal producer's often illicit but lighthearted tracks. Her best song, "The Forbidden Plum" from her Potion Activated EP, had elements of both. Dark, pulsing synth bleeps, a twisted metallic bassline and a prog house throwback gated vocal sit under a repeated refrain: "Want it so badly." "The Forbidden Plum" is a cocktail of hedonistic indulgence.—H.I.

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: BEAUTIFUL
items.description:
While SHERELLE expressed plenty of frustration over the pandemic in 2021—and even scolded the UK government in a broadcast for Newsnight—her debut EP was surprisingly light. The A-side, "160 Down The A406," is pure joy, featuring an airy chord progression, dreamy mallet melodies and chipmunk vocal cries all sewn into a breakbeat reverie. Although we can't in good faith recommend doing 160 MPH on the A406, we can put our weight behind this fuzzy footwork-jungle fusion, which showcases how SHERELLE can flex in the box just as much as she can behind the decks.—Emeka Okonkwo

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: MC Boing (Danny L Harle) - Boing Beat
items.label: Mad Decent
items.description:
MC Boing is one of the four new aliases Danny L Harle uses on his debut album. With "Boing Beat," he channels early '00s happy hardcore with spellbinding results. As part of the LP's virtual club experience—a four-story rave complex called Harlecore—Harle's tributes border on parody at certain moments. But at others he stumbles upon gold. "Boing Beat" is unapologetic, E'd-up euphoria taken to unnatural highs with MC Boing's manic vocals and Hannah Diamond's girlish, synthetic hook.. While Boing's half-screamed deliveries can be jarring at times, with lyrics as wholesome as "Everyone here is safe and nice / Makes me wanna have a great life," how could we do anything but smile and dance?—E.O.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
Between those buzzing synth lines and RJ Glasgow's robotic but commanding vocals, "Sick Bitch" by LSDXOXO could easily become this generation's "Satisfaction" by Benny Banassi. The Berlin-based producer and DJ pulled even fewer punches than usual on his XL Recordings debut, opting to go full thrust with lyrics so raunchy they'd leave a conservative news anchor on life support. Talk of testing gag reflexes and exploding in one's own clothes leaves nothing to the imagination and can put every room it's played in in an erotic headlock—or at least a sensual trance.—E.O.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Calibre & DRS v Mark Ernestus - Badder
items.label: Signature Records
items.description:
Basic Channel cofounder Mark Ernestus made a relatively rare turn to the mixing console with "Badder," linking up with drum & bass legend Calibre to craft understated and moody dub techno. The song samples the original "Badman," featuring DRS, and subtly riffs on its name. Things get hypnotic as DRS's vocal chops ripple and echo through the mix, while a snare that threatens to land never does. All the while, hi-hats tick ominously like the second hand on a watch. The shadows loom larger in this dark makeover, a bass-heavy maze rife with riveting tension.—E.O.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Hyperdub
items.description:
Press officers will tell you tunes are anthems when they're not. But Hyperdub wasn't messing around with "Anyway (Do It)." This club singalong is a blast of fresh air, blending gqom, amapiano and UK funky with an insanely catchy vocal about rolling spliffs and generally not giving a fuck. There's nothing more exciting than a new artist breaking through with absolute fire. On the strength of this banger and the rest of their excellent debut EP, 2022 could be a life-changing year for the burgeoning UK producer.—Carlos Hawthorn

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Astral Black
items.description:
Two wins stand out for Jossy Mitsu in 2021: becoming a resident at London club fabric and releasing her debut EP, Planet J. The impressive thing about her productions is how they echo her DJ sets, distilling a love of dubstep, UK garage, techno and jungle into a fresh, convincing package. The pick of the bunch was "Ø," named after Hyperdub's groundbreaking London party. The track's title informed its contents: dark, slinky and dripping in wall-rattling UK energy.—C.H.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Dais Records
items.description:
Listening to Honest Labour feels like street lights burning onto tired retinas and long nights of feeling small in a big city. On their sophomore album, producers Joshua Inyang and Joshua Reid created a series of nocturnal meditations, a series of nineteen short tracks bleeding into one another, in tribute to their hometown of Manchester. The duo's instrumentation is replete with field recordings of urban white noise, balanced by resonant cellos, hazy guitars and spectral guest performances with fragments of profound conversations—as if overheard from the night before—resulting in the audio equivalent of subconscious dreamscape. 

Put simply by Inyang and Reid themselves, Honest Labour is "an album about love and loss." The track "Indigo Grit," for instance, abruptly ends just as the speaker is about to explain the difference between liking and loving someone—a fleeting snippet of wisdom lost just before listeners could grab hold of it. But as with any inquiries into life’s most existential questions, the artists weren't intending to arrive at any conclusions. Through their album, they embraced the sheer mystery of the human experience, remaining at the mercy of their emotions just like the rest of us.—Emeka Okonkwo

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Haus of Altr
items.description:
AceMo and MoMA Ready have released a gob-stopping amount of music over the past few years, but their second album together, A Future, really put it all into perspective. The duo work in a well-worn transatlantic tradition, blending drum & bass, jungle and techno, but in their hands it feels cutting-edge as they jump from one tempo to the next with tangible excitement.  In spite of its name, the album is the sound of the duo creating a better present, of reimagining Afrofuturist narratives to suit the here-and-now rather than a distant future, of AceMoMA paving the way for everyone around them in New York and beyond.—Andrew Ryce

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: T4T LUV NRG
items.description:
After conquering the DJing circuit with a mix of psychedelic evangelism and irresistible old-school techno flair, Eris Drew started dipping her toes into production with vibrant results. On her debut album, Quivering In Time, she outdoes herself with nine tracks of club heat packing a festival-sized dose of euphoria into a retro sound palette of tight drum loops, breakbeats and dewy pads. She even includes a sample of psychonaut and ethnobotanist Terence McKenna to drive the point home. House music in 2021 hardly got much more ecstatic than this.—A.R.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Emeka Ogboh - Beyond The Yellow Haze
items.label: A-TON
items.description:
Is Beyond The Yellow Haze pretty funky for an art installation? Quite possibly. The original piece  catalogs the sounds of bustling Lagos—car horns, traffic, chatter. Those recordings, made into an album for A-TON—Ostgut Ton’s art-forward sublabel—forms  the foundation for ghostly broken techno that moves with the start-stop pulse of everyday life in the city. Ogboh's rich, layered atmospherics approximate fog and the motion blur of brake lights on a busy freeway, capturing the vibe of a city in the midst of immense growth, like a moment encased in amber.—A.R.

Listen: 
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: 4AD
items.description:
It's difficult to think of any other record this year that united more people from across different electronic music scenes than Sensational. Building on the Danish artist's Y2K R&B obsession and backed with lush yet subdued production from collaborator Central, it is a quiet storm of plucked strings, ornate piano and pitter-patter drums. De Casier's hushed voice  alternates between vulnerable and sarcastic, full of biting phrases and memorable one-liners: "You gotta be polite if you wanna roll with me." It’s the kind of music that's made for both memorable dance floor moments and cryptic Instagram captions directed at you-know-who.—A.R.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: George Riley - interest rates, a tape
items.label: Self-released
items.description:
It's tempting to call George Riley an old soul given her use of R&B vocals over '90s-influenced jazzy breaks, but that wouldn't do justice to her first mixtape, which felt ambitious even at its most relaxed. Her words come out in a stream-of-consciousness blur, revealing and incisive in their casual, say-whatever-comes-to mind-flow ("I don't want any man / Full stop!"). Oliver Palfreyman's beats feel dynamic and fluid, as if tailored to every twist and turn in Riley's sinuous vocal melodies. Dark, uplifting and sometimes even funny, it is one of the most striking R&B debuts of the year—Afrofuturism tuned to a very personal frequency.—A.R.

Listen:
Spotify / Apple Music

items.label: Peak Oil
items.description:
With Invariant, Hoavi set a new standard for what you might call ambient jungle. Combining the luxe atmospherics of dub techno, the fidgety pulse of footwork and the acrobatic loop-de-loops of jungle, the Russian producer's album is uncommonly beautiful, blowing minds while soothing them at the same time. You can pick any track at random and find something to obsess over—the breakcore-in-the-clouds of "Dver," the Balearic funk of "Streamline." But the LP is best taken as a whole, a wash of creamy chords and aerodynamic drum programming.—A.R.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: Virtual Dreams: Ambient Explorations In The House & Techno Age, 1993-1997
items.label: MUSIC FROM MEMORY
items.description:
Landing at the very end of 2020, when so many of us were deep in another round of lockdowns, Music From Memory's Virtual Dreams compilation was practically made for daydreaming in your bedroom. Bringing together some of the finest downtempo cuts from both lesser-known names like MDA Analog and lesser-known projects from established  names (like Move D and Roman Flügel), the compilation creates a half-lidded world where kick drums dreamily float in and out of focus. Virtual Dreams maps a time when the boundaries between electronic music for the club and the living room weren’t totally solidified, occupying a corridor space between the chill-out room and the dance floor. —Henry Ivry.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Limousine Dream
items.description:
Gene On Earth's The Sound of Limo compilation is a roster of the artists du jour  of the new minimal scene, providing documentary evidence of a vital corner of the underground while also working surprisingly well as a cohesive album. Each producer gathered here, from Sugar Free to Dyed Soundorom, has their own quirks, but certain throughlines—chunky basslines, swung drums, cascading video game bleeps—define a sub-genre of a sub-genre unto themselves. The music here is club-ready tech house, but the flourishes of fluorescent synth and often wacky melodies make it as whimsical as it is functional.—H.I.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Soundcloud

items.label: Ilian Tape
items.description:
Clocking in at over an hour and 45 minutes, Pool demanded  a commitment to active listening when it dropped. But Skee Mask has always excelled in the album format, and the extended run time allowed him to cover more ground than ever before. Pool takes the plunge into the sui generis cannabis haze of its soundscapes, where Skee Mask put his love of ambient atmosphere and UK dance music into conversation with bits of soulful funk, jazz and some of his fastest tempos yet (Pool went north of the 170 Arctic Circle at points). But, as only Skee Mask can, he creates an immersive and singular trip where genres come second to the textural richness and detail of his soundscapes, which range from danceable to stop-you-in-your-tracks gorgeous—H.I.

Listen:
Bandcamp / SoundCloud

items.label: bié RECORDS
items.description:
Yu Su's steady stream of dance-adjacent 12-inches over the past four years established a dusky and increasingly ornate twist on the Vancouver house sound, but her debut album Yellow River Blue took her somewhere entirely new, both figuratively and literally. The album functions both as a travel diary and love song. It documents a tour through her native China from Qingdao to the far-west city of Xining, recorded in different cities across the country where Yu Su both reconnected with her homeland and found a whole new community of electronic producers she was previously cut off from. The album is appropriately restless and exploratory, as Yu Su charts a path through geography and genres, from slo-mo breakbeat to Krautrock to dubby downtempo. —H.I.

Listen: 
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Perila - How Much Time It Is Between You And Me?
items.label: Smalltown Supersound
items.description:
Aleksandra Zakharenko, alongside similar-minded artists like Ulla and Ben Bondy, makes ambient music that breaks the mold: it's not necessarily intended to bring you solace and definitely won't make an easy soundtrack for any hotel lobbies (or elevators). How Much Time It Is Between You And Me?, is just as unsettling and eerie as it is delicate. The album uses these mixed emotions—as well as touches of post-rock melodrama and angst—to create a liminal state between waking and dreaming held together by Zakharenko's voice, which guides you through labyrinths that can be nightmarish but, just as quickly, morph into luxurious daydreams. —H.I.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Andy Stott - Never The Right Time
items.label: Modern Love
items.description:
It's been a decade since Andy Stott released the pair of EPs that introduced us to the dubby world of "knackered house." Since then, the UK artist's music has incorporated decaying memories of pop, like a ghostly outline caught in a photograph, through his ongoing collaborations with Alison Skidmore. Never The Right Time polished that rusting patina into Stott's most accessible album to date. "Don't Know How" is, by his standards, nearly bubblegum. This was true across the board on the record—even the abrasive mechanical rain of "Answers" ends with an uplifting, choral melody. Stott hasn’t lost his penchant for darkness, but now he isn’t  afraid of contrasting it with bold and bright bursts of colour either.—H.I.

Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify / SoundCloud

items.label: Stroboscopic Artefacts
items.description:
Stroboscopic Artefacts has been a hub for no-frills experimental techno for more than a decade, modeling itself in the restrained but psychedelic-friendly image of label owner Lucy. Following a year-long hiatus in 2020—after Lucy released a ten-year compilation of sleek dance floor cuts by mostly old guard artists—the label returned with the surprising self-titled LP from Bangkok-based Wanton Witch. The album opens a new chapter for Stroboscopic Artefacts, not only by featuring a queer, trans outsider artist, but by presenting a volatile, rave-adjacent sound palette beyond the label's wheelhouse. Wanton Witch dive-bombes and detonates with apocalyptic thuds and hardstyle drum fills, marking a new and exciting turn for the imprint and for Alegria's blossoming career. —Chloe Lula

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Merge Records
items.description:
Dawn Richard's sixth album—and first for the indie giant Merge—introduces her Afrofuturist alter ego, the golden, feather-plumed cyborg King Creole, who Richard described as an "assassination of stereotypes." Working Black-rooted genres like bounce and footwork into her usual experimental R&B, Richard balances a sense of play with her core strengths as a vocalist. "Bussifame" explodes with rallying whoops and commanding swagger, "Jacuzzi" aches with crooning sensuality, and "FiveOhFour (a lude)" switches to a braggadocious snarl. In tandem with intimate audio clips of her mother’s musings on love and Louisiana, it is a kaleidoscopic portrait of Richard's inner world and Southern heritage in glossy, florid detail. —Whitney Wei

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Mexican Summer
items.description:
L'Rain's second album meditates on the seismic complexities of a single emotion—grief—and its ability to exhaust and to destabilize, but to also spur personal evolution. Fatigue swoons into a tender revelry, both in terms of L'Rain's purring vocals and her warm, glowing productions, where the jangling piano keys and melancholic punctuation of saxophone dance around grainy sound recordings. It reminds listeners that sadness is so often site-specific. As a born-and-raised Brooklyner, L'Rain's singular blend of jazz, neo soul and ambient bears the heaviness of her urban environs on top of an already bruised psyche. —W.W.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Spotify / Apple Music  / Soundcloud

items.label: NTS
items.description:
If anything's apparent from the past few years, it's that dance music is inherently political. The most exciting dance music genre in the world at the moment—amapiano—demonstrates this point in a strikingly literal manner. Born in the townships in Gauteng, South Africa, the fledgling post-kwaito genre is the sound of joy in the midst of struggle. Now it's sweeping the globe. Amapiano Now, the 16-track compilation from NTS, is a bluffer's guide to the new South African dance phenomenon. From established acts like Vigro Deep and Gaba Canal to upstarts like Teno Afrika, the Shannen SP and Joe Cotch-curated collection demonstrates the inherent mid-tempo sensuality of amapiano, the thrilling sound of a generation of artists discovering their powerful collective voice. —Matt McDermott

Listen:
Spotify / Soundcloud

items.text: Floating Points, Pharoah Sanders & The London Symphony Orchestra - Promises
items.label: Luaka Bop
items.description:
Reading over the personnel for Promises, one might expect a grandiose statement—a multigenerational spiritual jazz odyssey for the ages. Instead, Sam Shepherd and the legendary Pharoah Sanders show a staggering knack for subtlety. Building upon a searching motif of four seven-note chords, both Shepherd and Sanders play with extraordinary humility. The careful arrangements serve as a backdrop for Sanders' restrained sax soloing, but the record doesn’t headline one artist over the other. Instead it reaches for an ineffable oneness, the pinnacle of improvised exploration. Each gradual change feels monumental, like the spaced-out synth exploration on "Movement 7" or the Hammond organ passed through a vibrating Leslie speaker on "Movement 8." That Promises holds its own—and even stands out—within one of the most important catalogues in jazz is a remarkable achievement. —M.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: DJ Manny - Signals In My Head
items.label: Planet Mu
items.description:
2021 was a golden year for footwork. This year, Planet Mu, once responsible for thrusting the Chicago genre onto the international stage in the mid-'10s, put out a trilogy of releases from stalwarts of this syncopated world: Jana Rush, RP Boo and DJ Manny. On Manny's contribution, the veteran Chicago-born, Brooklyn-based artist sought to bring romance to a genre historically known for soundtracking dance battles. If anyone could step up to this challenge, it would be DJ Manny and his smooth production style. Signals In My Head sees him whipping up some of the most airy atmospheres footwork has ever seen. Rosy melodies swirl into delirium while R&B vocals coo, sometimes lustfully and other times longingly, mellowing out its characteristically rougher rhythms and leaving only traces of a harder past.—Kiana Mickles
                
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Rough Trade
items.description:
Dean Blunt has long been an elusive character, quietly releasing oblique albums without liner notes and responding to interview questions in riddles. His entire body of work could be viewed like a museum of intriguing abstract paintings, open to interpretation but always astonishing. His most recent record riffs on its predecessor's Americana themes—heart-tugging strings, whining harmonica, desert rock guitar and somber and occasionally tongue-in-cheek lyrics that allude to loss, betrayal and the white critic's flimsy observations. But with the help of Joanne Robertson's girlish voice, as if brought down straight from heaven, Black Metal 2 emerges as one of Blunt's most approachable records. —K.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Domino
items.description:
If Tirzah's breakout debut album Devotion was beloved for its intimate romantic love songs, the tracks on Colourgrade will be remembered for expanding the definition of what constitutes a love song in the first place. Moving out of the city and giving birth to two children, Tirzah examined other forms of love, like the camaraderie between creative partners or the bond between parent and child. Some tracks here make it difficult to parse whether she is referring to a lover, a relative or an old childhood friend, but the universality of it all makes Colourgrade a record that will age gracefully with repeated listens. Adding to its introspective beauty and warmth, the album is brought to life with grainy production and endearing imperfections (a cough here, incomprehensible whispers there). Charmingly unpolished and grounded in a human need we can all agree on—love—it's an album that encourages listeners to cherish life's smallest, most precious moments. —K.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: N & J Blueberries
items.description:
People rarely talk about their favourite "band" anymore. HTRK, the Australian duo comprising Jonnine Standish and Nigel Yang, are one of a handful of groups that inspire this level of dedication in their fans. Their music holds similar qualities to other classic "favourite bands," like The Cure—their songs microcosms of ineffable longing and desolation. On their latest LP Rhinestones, HTRK continue to embrace stripped-down guitars, this time going for a twang and effects palette that evokes the Kodachrome skies of Wim Wenders' Paris, Texas. In the film, the sprawling vistas and stark photography set the stage for a hushed, heartbreaking drama. Here, the sparse guitar and unhurried progressions serve a similar purpose, foregrounding Standish's languid vocals.  As usual, deceptively simple lines like"If you wanted to / Hang out with mе during the day," on "Sunlight Feels Like Bee Stings," hit like a brick. —M.M.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
Long gone is the Joy Orbison who only makes club bangers. In his place sits a producer whose music is, with every new release, a truer, more vivid expression of not only his ever-broader tastes, but also his life and loves. Building on recent experiments with R&B and downtempo music, still slipping vol. 1 incorporates voice notes from his family—asking Joy how he's doing, making jokes, talking about weed brownies—into a cosy world of tunes that range from sedate garage to hooky, subdued pop. It feels like a Sunday afternoon in Joy's living room: vinyl all over the floor, loved ones popping in and out and talented friends occasionally jumping on the mic, all culminating into a more relaxed look at one of UK dance music's most quietly virtuosic producers.—Carlos Hawthorn

Listen:

Bandcamp / Spotify / Apple Music

items.label: Gobstopper Records
items.description:
It can take artists years—decades, even—to be able to authentically express themselves through their music. Mr. Mitch said this personal change occurred around the release of his 2017 album, Devout, a vulnerable record inspired by fatherhood. Not coincidentally, it was also the first time his fans had truly embraced his experimentations with slower tempos, ornate instrumentation and song-oriented structures. The Londoner built on this newfound freedom and confidence on this year's Lazy, with 11 tracks packing a range of energies and emotions. There are heart-rending tributes to his own musician father and strong statements about racism and social justice (the title is a reference to stereotypes about Black people), blending not only genres but personal and political messages in a way that could have felt forced and overblown in less accomplished hands. Instead, one feels profoundly moved. —C.H.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Hyperdub
items.description:
The late and great Mark Fisher feared that musical ingenuity was being replaced by desperate revivalism in the dying embers of late capitalism. If he was around now, Reflection might soothe those fears. James' mesmerising neo-IDM classic gestures towards dance music or bedroom R&B, only to take sudden detours into terra incognito that eludes categorisation altogether. (Nothing feels more appropriate than the outro being titled "We're Building Something New.") Sludgy, off-kilter kicks thud under pensive chords like some alien life form's interpretation of dance music. At times heartbreaking, at others startlingly vulnerable, James contemplates pandemic-era existentialism, projecting anxieties about the future with a ghostly delivery that feels like inner monologues being broadcast for all to hear: "This is a reflection / Just mine, not yours." —E.O

Listen:
Bandcamp / Spotify / Apple Music  / Soundcloud

items.text: Arushi Jain - Under The Lilac Sky
items.label: Leaving Records
items.description:
Arushi Jain has a buzzy, larger-than-life personality, but you'd hardly know that from her restrained and gentle music. Constantly jumping from project to project, Jain always found solace in Indian classical compositions when feeling overwhelmed, and wanted her own work to channel the same healing qualities. On her second full-length, she captures the evening light in all its ever-changing glory, moving from sunset to darkness. Humming synths and drones conjure the flickering shadows of twilight, while her voice adds bursts of vivid colour. Aimed at instilling a certain kind of intentionality and meditation in its listeners, Under The Lilac Sky is a guaranteed palette cleanser for those seeking clarity or simply enjoying an evening wind-down.—Nyshka Chandran

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Love Injection
items.description:
The self-titled debut from New York ensemble Conclave is a masterful study in rhythmic flexibility. True to their jazz roots, the group of rotating musicians—led by DJ and multi-instrumentalist Cesar Toribio—start the record as improvisational jams before narrowing down a vision and a concept. Their live approach is tangible: several tracks start on simple refrains before morphing into full-bodied flurries of dreamy funk, Afro-Latin percussion and downtempo beats. In homage to the clave (an instrument and rhythmic pattern), Toribio and his players concoct a joyous commemoration of the power of collaboration, unity and the cathartic energy of house music itself.—N.C.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Spotify / Apple Music  / Soundcloud

items.label: Warp Records
items.description:
On her Warp Records debut, London-based harpist and modular synthesist Nala Sinephro creates introspective electronic soundscapes with warm exhortations from the UK jazz new guard (musicians like Nubya Garcia and Eddie Hick). Combining ambient music and spiritual jazz, Space 1.8 lands like a caress, owing to Sinephro's intuitive touch—she knows exactly when to press, linger or just hold still. "While my hands are doing their job, I’m almost sleepwalking," she told The Guardian in a recent interview. Ranging from meditative to pulsating—with an incredible, career-making 17-minute finale—Sinephro's ambitious but effortless compositions comfort and soothe in all the right places. —N.C.

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

2020's busiest electronic artist might have been Wyatt D. Stevens, AKA MoMa Ready. Beyond the dozen or so records he produced himself (including an LP with AceMo and two solo albums), there were the ten he released on his label, HAUS Of ALTR, three of which were towering achievements in themselves: HOA 10, 11 and 12, compilations of more than 25 tracks each, released in June, July and September, each of them presenting, in their own words, "the future of Black electronic music," the "Vangaurd in the war against white supremacy in electronic music," and a "march toward a future of unabashed Black electronic expression." These 72 tracks show dozens of vital artists from New York and beyond delivering their A-game or something close to it. Together, they form an embarrassment of riches we're still getting through half a year later. 

Listen: Bandcamp HOA010 / HOA011 / HOA12

On September 1st, Slikback released ///, a surprise album that, at 30 tracks, doubled the size of the Nairobi artist's catalog in one fell swoop. Three days later, he released another 30-track bundle, ///||. He called them "a reflection of different vibes and emotions that make me... some rough, some gentle, some funny." The energy and artistry of these 60 tracks is stunning. Gqom, trap, noise, ambient, drill, footwork and techno all get tossed into Slikback's musical wood-chipper. Tempos run from around 70 BPM to over 170. Guest appearances range from Polish sound artist Morgiana Hz to the Ugandan MC Swordman Kitala. These albums should not be an easy listen—they clang, groan, shriek and bang, and sneak up on you when you least expect it. But instead of wearing you down, each new track lures you further in. You never know what kind of perfectly sideways groove is lurking around the corner. 

Listen: Bandcamp ///  / Bandcamp /​/​/ II

items.text: KMRU Peel + opaquer  Editions Mego + Dagoretti Records
items.description:
It's fitting that 2020 would produce a breakout star from the realms of ambient and field recording. Kenyan artist Joseph Kamaru, AKA KMRU, had been bubbling up already, but in 2020 he seemed to be everywhere, dropping tracks on his Bandcamp, appearing on the excellent Physically Sick 3, and releasing these two stunning LPs (along with a cassette, Jar) that show the incredible breadth of his sound. Appearing on esteemed avant-garde outlet Editions Mego, Peel is a silky abyss of droning soundscapes and spectral field recordings. Opaquer is its adventurous counterpart, with tracks like "Lost Ones" and "Canthenta" having more in common with bass-heavy experimental music than anything you'd typically call ambient. Together, they introduced many of us to an artist whose music is as powerful as it is subtle. 

Peel: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify opaquer: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Ulla Tumbling Towards A Wall  Experiences Ltd
items.description:
It doesn't lull you into a vegitative state, nor evoke a hotel spa lobby via rainforest field recordings. Instead, the side of ambient Ulla conjures on tumbling towards a wall carries you away with the subtlety of a daydream. The Kansas City artist has worn many aesthetic hats over the years, both on previous releases like Append and in projects like Pontiac Streator and the newly minted LOG. Her delicate compositional ear is clearer than ever on this release. Tracks like "stunned suddenly" and "new poem'' create space to think, without trying too hard to relax you. "feeling remembering," "leaves and wish" and "soak" are spotted with melodies and gentle textures—the album is ripe with soothing sounds, but never cluttered with them. You walk away from tumbling towards a wall feeling like the artist has told you something personal, a secret, and a precious one at that, even if you can't say exactly what it is. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

In the seven years since her debut album, E.M.M.A. has gotten comfortable composing soundtracks and scores—her recent work has found her soundtracking campaigns for luxury fashion houses like Gucci and Chanel. Her affinity towards large-scale, cinematic projects is reflected in the brief 35 minutes that make up Indigo Dream. Swirling '80s synths and club sounds collide on this mesmerizing album, sending us to the zenith of yearnful nostalgia and back again. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

Even within Theo Parrish's catalogue, Wuddaji felt like a monumental entry. After innovating an often-imitated, never-replicated brand of deep house around the turn of the millennium, Wuddaji's eight tracks felt like a new milestone, or a jumping off point for some new, deliriously funky Black dance music. Dense, futuristic tunes like "Hennyweed Buckdance" are interspersed with floor-fillers like "Angry Purple Birds" and "This is For You." Wuddaji came with a map of Idlewild, a once-thriving vacation enclave in Northwestern Michigan that saw the likes of Aretha Franklin and Louis Armstrong performing for Black audiences escaping segregation in St. Louis and Detroit. Wuddaji, like so much of his music, draws from the personal and the historical, musical and otherwise. His deep understanding of the triumphs and injustices of the past—and their impact on the present—is raw material for groundbreaking art.

Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud  / Sound Signature

items.text: BOOF Rebirth Of Gerberdaisy  Bubble Tease Communications
items.description:
Maurice Fulton has a lighthearted, often humorous approach to dance music, and it's safe to say that BOOF is his quirkiest project. These records come out once every five years or so, are always named after flowers and feature elementary artwork that looks like it was made in Microsoft Paint (a stretched flower and clashing text). But beneath that exterior is some of the best work the American multi-instrumentalist has ever put out. Rebirth Of Gerberdaisy is no exception. In fact, it's the best BOOF record yet, with the gusto of a talented live band trying to work out as many dance genres as they can: minimal techno, piano house, stomping disco, jazz fusion and deep, soulful grooves. Of course it's not a band you're hearing, just Fulton going crazy on the organ, guitar and keyboards, a one-of-a-kind talent that makes every genre sound like something he invented.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

The idea of the lone genius is appealing, but most great records are the labor of many minds. On Workaround, South London-born artist Beatrice Dillon embraces the collectivity of music-making, weaving together acoustic instrumentation from 12 different collaborators with her software production techniques to create 14 rhythmically complex toe-tappers, all fixed at 150 BPM. Batu brings the hi-hats on "Workaround Six," which are nonchalantly assembled into a beat, while the malevolent thwack of stand-up bass comes courtesy of Swedish jazz musician Petter Eldh. "Workaround Two" has flushed synths and vocals from Laurel Halo. Dillon's catalogue is an advent calendar of distinct treats, containing dub techno abstractions such as 2015's Face A, experimental cassettes like Index Tape For Performance and Two Changes (with Rupert Clervaux). Workaround, galvanized by a crush on UK dance music, is cultivated through the diligent practice of purposeful limitation. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

At the beginning of July, four months into the pandemic and six weeks into daily protests following the murder of George Floyd by police, Allergy Season and Discwoman dropped Physically Sick 3, a charity compilation that raised money for Equality For Flatbush, an organization fighting police brutality and gentrification that also helped residents of Brooklyn stay safe during COVID-19. Curated by Physical Therapy, Umfang and Frankie Decaiza Hutchinson, the music was exceptional—27 tracks of bold club sounds, plus the odd bit of noise and ambient, from a cast of artists that spanned continents and generations. The series' tradition of what it once called "electronic protest music" had never felt more necessary, and it was inspiring to see electronic artists rising to the occasion so readily. Beyond being some of the best music that came out this year, Physically Sick 3 was a how-to in DIY music activism. 

Listen: Bandcamp

items.text: Ana Roxanne Because Of A Flower  Kranky
items.description:
Ana Roxanne's debut record, ~~~, had ambient fans in the palm of her hand, eagerly awaiting a follow-up. Her sound instantly had its own niche, drawing from New Age, devotional music and drone. Because Of A Flower is a more confident record than her first. It's conceptually provoking and brilliantly executed, full of vulnerability and understated beauty. Her enchanting vocals elevate Because Of A Flower above your typical ambient fare. It's a refined set of songs that seem to fly by and leave you in a different, more serene mood from where you started.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

Many of the most cherished post-punk pop records—Young Marble Giants' Colossal Youth, Gareth Williams & Mary Currie's Flaming Tunes—are scrappy projects held together by spit and glue. Jonnine's Blue Hills fits that bill. Recorded at HTRK member Jonnine Standish's home in the Dandenong Ranges outside Melbourne, the nine-track album was a low-key affair, first released on cassette as part of Boomkat's series of quarantine records, Documenting Sound. But the spare songs, built on less-is-more bass lines and Standish's spectral vocals, punched above their weight with their effortless mix of the mundane and the sublime. "And hey, you're the best thing that I've had / because you want all the things that I have / And when the birds sing / they sing just for you / they live in blue hills," Standish sang, guiding the listener through the small psychodramas of a life lived in lockdown at the edge of the forest.

Listen: Boomkat

Maybe you saw Moodymann in the flesh this year. Or caught his residency at Grand Theft Auto's new nightclub, The Music Locker. Most of us weren't so lucky. Instead, we sought consolation in Taken Away, a record so quintessentially Kenny Dixon Jr. it could probably form the basis of a biography. Detroit? Tick. Roller skating? Tick. Track after track of toasty gospel, house and hip-hop, peppered with sultry, sometimes madcap musings from the "most memorable voice in modern dance music"? Obviously. This LP had it all. Behold a masterclass in house music songwriting. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.text: Yves Tumor Heaven To A Tortured Mind  Warp Records
items.description:
The highlight of Yves Tumor's show-stopping fourth album is "Kerosene," a collaboration with the singer Diana Gordon that isn't so much a duet as a collision, rising to a churning climax where Gordon's vocals feel like a cross between Dolores O'Riordan and Alanis Morrisette. It's a moment of fireworks on an album that functions like a powder keg, a 21st-century rock opera starring Tumor, flanked by an arsenal of session musicians and armed with oodles of vaporwave-style loops. Here, amid horn sections that rise up like tidal waves and guitar leads that go up against clipped funk samples, Yves Tumor emerges as something like the rock star they've tried to be for years: sexy, alien, suave, and a master of melodies that get stuck in your head.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

No one knows much about techno producer Shinichi Atobe. The Saitama-based artist has been releasing albums on DDS for five years now, with the only communication between him and the label typically consisting of no more than a CD with track titles in the mail. Building on the warm housey elements that were the foundation's of 2018's Heat, Yes is chock full of bright melodies, and of course delivered with his trademark hi-fi production standard. There are also a few surprises, too, like the sci-fi synths on "Lake 3," the funk-driven pulse of "Ocean 1" and the Drexciyan touch of "Loop 1." 

Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

There's always excitement around an Actress album, but for this year's Karma & Desire, Darren Cunningham and Ninja Tune went the extra mile. There was a prequel mixtape, which included a cryptic teaser tracklist for the album proper. There was a short film and a hotline you could call to hear a track down the phone. For a few days, rumours even spread of a second Actress mixtape, but it turned out to be the work of Dam Voyage. After all that, Karma & Desire had to be good. Cunningham delivered on the build-up and then some. What we got was a more open and fun version of Actress's early sound. The vocalists made the record more accessible. The instrumentals, too, were brighter and clearer. The album experience, its innovative preamble included, was a clear highlight of 2020.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

Duval Timothy's fourth album has a documentary writer's touch. With his piano front-and-center, the LP narrates a journey of healing and navigating the perils of the music industry, primarily drawing on minimalist jazz hooks and immersive sampling. Timothy has a gift for making gems out of the mundane. On Help, spare vocals are distorted and looped into oddball rhythms, while field recordings bring the compositions to life. It's one of those special, emotive albums that says a lot by doing less.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Yaeji What We Drew 우리가 그려왔던  XL Recordings
items.description:
After creating dance floor bangers so universal they had festival crowds sing along with them, Yaeji took a backseat, preferring to collaborate and curate rather than release the long-awaited follow-up to her breakthrough EPs. What We Drew is a candid study of depression and ennui, how to break free from those things, and how to avoid beating yourself up when you do feel bad. The lead single is a tribute to the act of living: "I got hydrating down / I got listening down," she sings. On "Money Can't Buy," her guest Nappy Nina says, "Snuggly and sleepy / These naps come easy" after a verse of braggadoccio. What We Drew makes it clear that Yaeji connects with audiences around the world because she presents life as it is, celebrating the triumph of persevering and just getting the small things down, supported by love not only from others, but for yourself, too.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

More than most techno producers, Jasmine Infiniti embodies the euphoric potential of the genre alongside its darker impulses. Take "Downhill," where muddy drums thump beneath bright, neon-streaked synths. The American artist's debut album straddles this divide so well because of Jasmine Infiniti's lived experience as a person on the margins, where nightlife can be a trap as much as an escape. But for every moment of foreboding, there's a glimpse of light, underpinned by an elastic, almost buoyant sense of melody and rhythm, informed by her days in the Bay Area's vogue scene and the taut slap of ballroom music. It's a techno record unlike any other in 2020—heavy and light, ecstatic and paranoid.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

The authorities coming down hard on Black music is nothing new, but the story around UK drill felt different. This time, even hugely influential platforms like YouTube shared in the vilification, removing videos at the request of the police. That was in 2018, which is incredible when you consider how far the genre has come since then. No one better embodies this turnaround than poster boy Headie One, whose excellent debut album, Edna, felt like a watershed moment for UK drill. Here was a #1 record laying bare the glory and despair of gang life in London, told through the eyes of not only its protagonist but a whole cast of rap stars, from local legends (M Huncho, Ivorian Doll) to global icons (Drake). Once again, Black street music, through a combination of grit and pure talent, had silenced its critics and conquered the mainstream.

Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

Anz
 spring/summer dubs 2020


Anz's fifth production mix, spring/summer dubs 2020, was "built through turbulence and forged in feeling," yet somehow the tracks are fizzing with euphoria. Taken from an arsenal of a whopping 74 tracks made during quarantine, the UK producer compiled 84 minutes of summery UK dance music into this mix, which fans out over UK funky, 2-step garage, dubstep and jungle. The edit samples range from '90s hip-hop and R&B to the TikTok favorite "Renegade," which is remixed with raucous amen breaks.















Conducta
The Kiwi Sound

Two years, two unbelievably good mixes from Conducta. The Kiwi Sound, the follow-up to 2019's #1 pick, hits many of the same notes: bouncy, bright and stacked with the best in fresh UK garage. It's a bold statement on the health of the modern scene, which has taken years to break through despite UK garage never really going away. Finally, everyone's favourite summer sound is back where it belongs: in the hands of young, talented tastemakers with the world at their feet.















FAUZIA
DISCWOMAN 87 

"Almost didn't do this as I didn't think it was good enough," FAUZIA says of her DISCWOMAN mix, "but my friends forced me to see it through!" The idea of this all-originals mix not being good enough becomes almost impossible to conceive about halfway through, when she's blasted her way through Plaid-style IDM, throbbing deep house and stonking dubstep. The mix seems to catch the artist just as she's found her voice, like a bolt of lightning captured in a photograph. As tracks from it have trickled out on various releases through the year, FAUZIA's star has only grown brighter. This mix, frozen in time, is basically where it all started.















Scott Zacharias & Patrick Russell
IT.podcast.s09e05 & IT.podcast.s09e01

For a small but dedicated group within rave culture, it goes without saying that No Way Back, arguably the last vestige of the hallowed Midwest rave tradition, is the biggest event, of any kind, on the calendar all year.
