These two sets from this year's streamed edition show what's unique about the party, from the range of records played, to the peerless taste and panache of their selectors. Patrick Russell's set embodies No Way Back's bread and butter: leftfield techno and electro gems, drawn from decades of dedicated digging, perfectly arranged into a mind-bending slipstream of sound. Scott Zacharias, who usually plays the chillout room ("Outer Space") at sunrise, is the party's dessert, bringing a psychedelic soup of jazz, rock, dub, hip-hop, ambient, Italo, funk, soul and whatever else fits a sound he likes to call "sleaze." Together, these sets demonstrate the limitless possibilities not just of No Way Back, but of playing records in general. 















Job Jobse
Sunrise at the last ever Nachtdigital 

All 140 minutes of this glorious mix encapsulate why we’ve been missing clubbing so much in 2020. It has everything: pop hits, rave classics, the hiss of the Nachtdigital crowd cavorting in the dawn sun. Early on, the heavens opened, followed by hours of unabated sunshine. Friends frollicked in the lake, partners kissed and embraced, and Job Jobse, the master of ceremonies, surveyed the sandy dance floor with the grin of a man whose dreams had come true. Listening to this mix brings it all flooding back. 














Juliana Huxtable
Dekmantel 288

To take a line from one of her own poems, Juliana Huxtable’s Dekmantel Podcast contains a "PALPABLY HIGH LEVEL OF IDGAF ENERGY." The Texas-born artist is impatient behind the decks, knocking through visceral techno, vocal samples and industrial interventions with marvelous fluidity, compounding them into a hypnotizing sound collage that advances towards evermore stimulating sonic extremes. Change is a constant in this mix, and no genre is out of bounds. The permissive approach means it's packed with potential peak moments, poised and ready to encite euphoria for a range of listeners, whatever their niche. 















Nicolas Lutz
at Phonoteque

Nicolas Lutz has long been the maestro of playing records for which you'd happily trade a limb in return for an ID. Thanks to him and peers like Binh and DJ Masda, overlooked corners of house, techno, electro, trance and breakbeat history are now prime influences for a burgeoning audience of DJs and producers, many of whom might not have formerly paid mind to the so-called "minimal" scene from which those DJs emerged. This mix from Phonotheque—home base for Lutz, DJ Koolt and the rest of the Montevideo techno scene—shows things are coming full circle. More than ever, Lutz is playing new music that his sound has directly influenced. He's also reaching for records that fit into his taste bracket but come from sources you might not expect. It would've been unusual a few years ago that he'd play something by, say, Overmono. It speaks to how different parts of dance music are coming ever closer into orbit.














Theo Parrish
We Are All Gorgeous Monsterss

Theo Parrish's We Are All Georgeous Monsterss is more than a DJ mix: it's a casually delivered manifesto. In the fever pitch of the largest protest movement in US history, Parrish uploaded, revised and eventually pulled down an expansive six-part set that drew direct connections between racial violence and the appropriation of electronic dance music from its Black roots. "You don't know what this music means to us, you only know what it means to you," Parrish intoned. "Now granted, you take your ideas, you run with it, you create your own shit, that's great, you create your own universe of it. Please, go right ahead, there's nothing wrong with being inspired, but my god, you can't have all of it!" Quotes and archival interviews break up Parrish's own spoken word as he unfurls hours of unreleased material, spanning from melancholy jazz piano to frenetic beat tracks. All the while, the Detroit artist detailed various indignities, from being pulled over to getting kicked off the decks at Berghain. If this is what Parrish, a massively respected innovator within the form, faces day-to-day, what does that say about the general experience of Black artists within the club scene? What went wrong?















CCL
Blowing Up The Workshop 111

DJing isn't always art, but Blowing Up The Workshop, Matthew Kent's dearly departed mix series, reminded us that it often can be. The series was historically important, hosting mixes from Galcher Lustwerk and Ben UFO that stood the test of time. But the series also helped migrate the concept of DJing away from the utilitarian and towards the deeply personal. CCL's contribution to 111—the seven mixes that sent BUTW out on a high note—fit the bill. Kent described the set, which spanned from dream pop to dubstep, as "a beautiful collage that feels like the reason I started the series in the first place." Akash pulled together a wistful 30-minute set of Bollywood tunes for 111, complementing Chris SSG's masterful three-hour ambient set and Dr Banana's moody garage and 2-step mix, to name just a few. BUTW felt like a natural home for all of these disparate styles, and this freedom often led to mixes worth cherishing. Kent's now moved on from BUTW, focusing on Mana Records, the label he runs with Andrea Zarza, but with any luck, BUTW's boundless approach will persevere.

Theo Parrish
We Are All Gorgeous Monsterss

Theo Parrish's We Are All Georgeous Monsterss is more than a DJ mix: it's a casually delivered manifesto. In the fever pitch of the largest protest movement in US history, Parrish uploaded, revised and eventually pulled down an expansive six-part set that drew direct connections between racial violence and the appropriation of electronic dance music from its Black roots. "You don't know what this music means to us, you only know what it means to you," Parrish intoned. "Now granted, you take your ideas, you run with it, you create your own shit, that's great, you create your own universe of it. Please, go right ahead, there's nothing wrong with being inspired, but my god, you can't have all of it!" Quotes and archival interviews break up Parrish's own spoken word as he unfurls hours of unreleased material, spanning from melancholy jazz piano to frenetic beat tracks. All the while, the Detroit artist detailed various indignities, from being pulled over to getting kicked off the decks at Berghain. If this is what Parrish, a massively respected innovator within the form, faces day-to-day, what does that say about the general experience of Black artists within the club scene? What went wrong?

Josey In Space by Josey Rebelle Josey Rebelle Josey In Space Beats in Space Records In the first few minutes of Josey In Space, we hear beautiful poetry about the Black experience from Tenesha The Wordsmith and Daniel B. Summerhill, in the shimmering track "I Dream So Loud." "I've seen dreams deferred / As many times as I've seen kids wish upon them…. Now / Not later but right now / More than ever I dream so loud." In the next track, we hear a one-off vocal sample: "Can't we rebel or something?" Those words stay in our head as we listen to the rich, unpredictable, deeply personal mix that follows. The beauty of DJing is you can play literally whatever you want, something that Josey Rebelle, a DJ since the age of 13, understands more deeply than most. Josey In Space, the second official mix in Tim Sweeney's Beats In Space series, has the same eclectic flex as her club and radio sets, drawing an arc from '90s hardcore to chilled UK hip-hop via house, techno, acid and jungle. But it's also highly focussed, bringing together these disparate sounds to give us something carefully considered: a paean to Black club music over the last few decades, from both sides of the Atlantic. "Yes, music is beautiful, it makes you happy," Rebelle told Chal Ravens this year in a cover story for DJ Mag. "But it's also a serious business, and you approach those decks with serious intentions to destroy the dance floor." Here, Rebelle's intentions are less dance floor destruction, more musical storytelling. But the dedication to craft is no less intense. Arriving one year after the BBC's #1 Essential Mix of 2019, Josey In Space once again shows Rebelle to be one of her generation's best.

Josey Rebelle
Josey In Space 
Beats in Space Records

items.text: Eris Drew Fluids Of Emotion  Interdimensional Transmissions
items.description:
When "Fluids Of Emotion" came out in February, Matt Unicomb's review asked, "Could this be the house record of the year?" Eris Drew's track makes a strong case for the title, all psychedelic breakbeat house with the same feeling of controlled chaos you get from her quick-fingered mixing of old rave records. The bounding drums, the uplifting harpsichord, the misty-eyed vocal sample: it's all put together with the love and intense emotion that defines Drew's signature sound. "It's the kind of track that unites a dance floor, so I hope I'm lucky enough to be on one when it gets played," Unicomb said. Most of us are still waiting for that opportunity. Luckily, the charm of "Fluids Of Emotion" feels timeproof, a rapturous feeling encased in wax.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Nazar Bunker feat. Shannen SP  Hyperdub
items.description:
Guerrilla, the illuminating debut album by Nazar, taught us something about the Angolan civil war. Rarely has electronic music tackled complex themes—politics, bloodshed, trans-generational trauma—in such a raw and compelling way. "Bunker," the second collaboration with London DJ and curator Shannen SP, was inspired by real-life events in Luanda in 1992, when Nazar's two older sisters barricaded themselves inside hotel rooms to avoid being found by government death squads. The anxiety is there in the helicopter whirrs and the cocking of guns. Both artists murmur lyrics in the detached drone of the shellshocked. Is that a knock at the door? The whole thing makes for harrowing listening. But still you go back for more.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

It's like something from a nightmare: you release the biggest bomb of your life at a time when dance floors don't exist and socialising has been virtually outlawed. Not only that but your track is exceptionally festival-ready, all cosmic synths and fat breakbeats—the soundtrack, in other words, to a life-affirming dance floor moment. The good news is that "Outer Rim" isn't likely to be shelved any time soon. Tracks this special deserve a proper runout once parties return. Ravers must experience this beautiful banger in all its glory.

Listen: Youtube

items.text: DNGDNGDNG Hiperborea On The Corner Records
items.description:
Peruvian duo Dengue Dengue Dengue planned a new alias for 2020's festival circuit. Abbreviated to DNGDNGDNG, the alias hasn't yet had a chance to live out its original intentions, but it was behind one of the year's standout EPs. Continentes Perdidos channels the mystical sound of, as the name translates, lost continents. On the highlight "Hiperborea," DNGDNGDNG excavate and innovate their Afro-Peruvian heritage. The record is rooted in the unpredictability of polyrhythmic structure; your ears try to follow one rhythm and before long, you're lost in a jungle full of them.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Andrew Ashong & Kaidi Tatham Washed In You  Kitto Records
items.description:
Andrew Ashong's last two releases—a collaboration with Theo Parrish and the go-to soul of his self-titled EP—date back to 2012 and 2014, so by October of this year we were long overdue another hit of his silky smooth voice. His 2020 mini-album, Sankofa Season, was well worth the wait, especially with the added bonus of broken-beat hero Kaidi Tatham on the buttons. "Washed In You," the effortlessly cool lead single, is everything you could wish for from the collaboration. Tatham's production pedigree shines through the skippy drums and roaming arrangement. His lush keyboard playing is the perfect accompaniment to Ashong's voice, as well as having its own moments to take centre stage. Sankofa Season marked the beginning of a new label project for the pair, Kitto Records. Hopefully there's more to come, and sooner rather than later.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

INTe*ra is Vancouver's Hashman Deejay with PLO Man and C3Deee, two of the artists behind Acting Press. Aqueduct, their only release this year, shows what makes this label cult favorite, with six tracks that float between cosmic techno and a modern update of '90s West Coast ambient (see: Spacetime Continuum and his essential label, Reflective). "548" hovers gracefully between those sounds. Its atmosphere is part deep-sea, part deep-space, with a stepping techno pulse that enhances its weightless feel and a nine-minute runtime that makes it easy to get lost in. These guys do lush, transportive techno better than anyone, and this one showed them at the top of their game.

items.text: Kush Jones Strictly 4 My CDJZ Vol. 8  Self-released
items.description:
Kush Jones is committed to releasing 40 volumes of Strictly 4 My CDJZ. For anyone who follows the prolific producer's output, this goal seems well within reach. Opening the eighth volume of the EP series, "Bleep Bloop" is a clear standout from the series so far. There's punchy bass, soaring pads that drop and ascend like hovering airplanes, and as the cut's cheeky title references, an almost piercing melody that trickles throughout. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

items.text: Anz Loos In Twos (NRG)  Hessle Audio
items.description:
Anz was one of 2020's success stories. First she turned heads with her mammoth spring/summer dubs 2020 mixtape, showcasing over 50 original tracks. Then she landed on Hessle Audio, an essential label for the kind of hybrid UK dance music she makes and plays. Her status as Manchester's new hero was cemented with "Loos In Twos (NRG)," where old-school rave synth stabs and breakbeats conspire for a lunging rhythm that sounds like it was designed to knock the needle off the record. Like so much of her music, it's a rush of energy and a ray of much-needed sunshine, a SAD lamp for a world without dance floors.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Terrence Dixon Galactic Halo  Axis Records
items.description:
The great thing about electronic music is that new trends appear periodically, giving us all a dose of something fresh. The other great thing is that some artists never change. Terrence Dixon belongs to the latter camp, a Detroit maverick who for 25 years has put out a steady stream of reliably excellent cosmic techno. This year's contribution to the canon was the Galactic Halo LP, which looked ahead to life on a strange planet in the year 2976. The standout track was "Quasar," a wonderfully simple roller built from a few bleeps and bloops ducking and diving across a firm pulse. 

Listen: Axis Records

"Summer" is an anomaly on this list, as it was first released in 2000, during the golden era of dub techno. The Glaswegian artist Pub re-released it as a single this September, together with another glitchy ambient masterpiece on the flip. For many of us, this opened the floodgates to a vast and somewhat elusive discography, both his own and that of his prolific label, Ampoule.  "Summer" sprawls out over 16 minutes, wandering leisurely and striking a perfect middle ground between ambient and dub techno. Its free-flowing, blissed out atmospheres will work perfectly for fans of Deepchord, Barker or Jan Jelinek.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

Novelist wore several hats in 2020—UK drill rapper, house producer, jungle MC—but the most surprising and compelling was the silky '80s sound of "Stay With Me." This love letter to Jesus, which came complete with a catchy chorus and belting sax solo, spotlighted the London artist's pop appeal and songwriting chops. There was a deeper message, too. Uploaded to Bandcamp the day before a major Black Lives Matter protest in London, "Stay With Me" was about remaining strong and hopeful in the face of adversity.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

If there was a prize for the year's weirdest banger, it would have to go to Karenn's "Shoes Off." Blawan and Pariah lightened up their joint project in the past couple of years, from the artwork and track titles on their label, Voam, to the extremes of this trancey number. The austerity of their last label, Works The Long Nights, is a distant memory. That's not to say the new music doesn't bang as hard, but the pair seem intent on drawing more fun and unusual sounds out of their arsenal of hardware. "Shoes Off" is Exhibit A. Somehow a playful melody, gritty kicks and rips of bass gel together. For a moment you would be forgiven for thinking you're listening to Four Tet or Bicep, until the snarling bassline boxes you square in the face.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

The first two releases on WIP, the new label from Wata Igarashi, caught the Japanese techno maestro in a serene mood. By the third, he was back on the dance floor. "Eruption" is like listening to 2020 in microcosm. The mood begins pleasantly enough, before an industrial scrape, faint at first, swells to a deafening roar, the sound of planes crashing and buildings collapsing. A flash of white noise, then, quick as anything, the thunder slips away, leaving the kick drums and churning bassline, only this time there's something else too, all feathery and glorious. Light, perhaps, at the end of the tunnel.

Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

items.text: Donato Dozzy The Tao Samurai Music
items.description:
A Donato Dozzy drum & bass EP had been coming. His DJ sets have been incorporating more and more D&B, he has released a 170 BPM remix for Samurai Music already, and his label Spazio Disponibile has issued two 12-inches of half-time mind-melters from Mike Parker. "Tao," the title track from Dozzy's EP for Samurai, is a technical marvel and a fresh approach to 170 (or 85) BPM, borrowing heavily from his slow-release style of techno. The EP as a whole is another inspired, diagonal step in his discography.

Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

items.text: Azu Tiwaline Magnetic Service  Livity Sound
items.description:
Azu Tiwaline's sultry take on "meditation music" draws you into a deep and expansive listening experience. Refractions of her more dance-focused project Loan periodically pass through Magnetic Service, producing dub and minimal techno apparitions. All her releases under this moniker look to music as the coupling between humans and the natural world. Inspired by local environmental soundscapes in the El Djerid region of southern Tunisia where she lives, the EP has an elemental richness, thanks in part to her use of field recordings and atmospheric synths.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

"End Of The Night" comes as the relaxed, four-to-the-floor closer of an EP focused on electro and 2-step, like the exhausted but blissful finale of a good night out. It's a sumptuous cut of dream-house with warm pianos, blissful sustain strings and ELLES' shyly deadpan vocal delivery. What really makes this track special is all the little moments—the touches of bird song, the cymbal crashes after the breakdown, the way the vocals start to stutter and phase—that send chills down your spine. These are the ingredients that bittersweet club anthems are made of.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Nico Six Rooms EP  Akita Club
items.description:
Before releasing music as Nico, Mexican artist Nicolas Guerrero appeared on labels like L.I.E.S., Styles Upon Styles and Blank Slate, under the guise of White Visitation or WV. Since 2018, he has departed from the barreling techno of that alias, veering towards a more colourful and open-hearted sound. His 2020 mini-album Six Rooms goes further, in Nico's own words, "away from the club and into empty houses and abandoned pools." He has a way with vocal chops and syncopated drums—which attracted the keen ears of Batu's Timedance and Midnight Shift—and he deployed both gracefully on the Six Rooms highlight "One Day."

Listen: Bandcamp

"Run 2 U" is one of so many tracks released this year that longs to be played in a club. Tygapaw's debut album, Get Free, manages to be both tender and barreling, exploring self-liberation with meditative spoken word and dopamine-laced, '90s-Detroit influenced techno. Roughshod and bursting with energy, "Run 2 U" sits somewhere near the middle of the album. It's so entrancing that you might want run it back before continuing the journey. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

Giggs
Straight Murder (Giggs & David) feat. Dave 
No Bs Music
Giggs and Dave, the two big stars of UK rap, couldn't be more different: Giggs is all presence and cheeky punchlines, while Dave is pure lyrical wizardry. Turns out, their styles complement each other. "Straight Murder (Giggs & David)," their second collaboration, showed both rappers at the top of their games, Dave relentless and razor-sharp, Giggs somehow both jovial and vicious. The wordplay is mind-blowing. And let's give a special shout-out to KeyzMusic, the man behind one of the best and most chilling beats of 2020.

Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud








2020








India Jordan
For You 
Local Action



India Jordan wrote For You to document the process of coming to terms with their queer identity. Taking cues from happy hardcore, drum & bass and house, the record opens with blissful house tracks "I'm Waiting (Just 4 U)" and the title track, recalling the late-night euphoria of last year's DNT STP MY LV. The "you" here refers to Jordan, who has recently come out to the public as non-binary.

There's a feeling of triumph that emanates from "For You." The track shows Jordan's knack for chopping and looping vocal samples, this one employing the amorous hook of Change's "You Are My Melody." The loop never gets old, and as satisfying as the final climactic breakdown of the track is, when the familiar hook comes back around, it makes you wonder why it left in the first place. But the vocals aren't all that make the track pop. "For You" is swaddled in an addictive sunny feeling, thanks to funky guitar riffs, seesawing '80s synths and rousing percussion. The track captures the dizzying joy of finding true love—in this case, the love of one's self. 


Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud












if(window && !!window.LazyLoad){new window.LazyLoad({elements_selector:".lazy"});}

Kelela & Asmara Aquaphoria Originally aired as part of Warp's NTS takeover, Kelela and Asmara's Warp mixtape feels like a jam session between friends. Asmara sculpts an undulating backing track out of music from Aphex Twin, Suzanne Kraft & Jonny Nash and Kareem Lotfy—artists that have helped define the recent era of ambient music. Kelela's airy, improvised vocals act are the perfect counterpart to Jaco Pastorius' genius bass solo and Iury Lech's emotional washes. They bring this floating, beatless music to an unforgettable climax. Lena Willikens & Vladimir Ivkovic Live: Nuits Sonores 2019 Headlining festival sets don't always work outside the original setting—as with well-timed jokes, you kinda had to be there. But leave it to Lena Willikens and Vladimir Ivkovic to make their three-hour Nuits Sonores odyssey suit nearly any context. It's meditative, weird and, lest we forget the main room dance floor it soundtracked, banging. Filled with the pair's characteristic slower selections, this mix feels like swimming inside a crystal ball. CCL Unsound Podcast 56 CCL called this mix a "regurgitated memory" of their Honcho Campout set, reflecting on the "more twisted hours… before the light had come up." That predawn unpredictability is what's so exciting here. One highlight is their adept pulling back with Codek's "Closer" before diving into a Metalheadz Wax Doctor rush. With these unreal transitions, and touches like the experimental Polish music that bookends the mix (a nod to Unsound) CCL shows the careful craft that sets them apart. Truly Madly GHOSTCAST 006 Ghostcast, a mix series from Berlin's favourite record store on wheels, has only released a few recordings since launching two years ago, but each is a window into a world of deep-digging DJs with exquisite house and techno collections. Truly Madly is one of them. An underground favourite who's steadily gaining recognition outside the world of trainspotters and Discogs geeks, the Londoner's set traverses classic techno, electro and house, cloaked with the same spacey charm that colours his club sets. Boards Of Canada Societas x Tape (NTS x Warp 30) Boards Of Canada are two of the most reclusive artists in electronic music, which means we don't know much about what they listen to during long stays in the Scottish countryside. Their Societas x Tape mix, a two-hour set broadcast on NTS as part of Warp's 30th anniversary, gives us an idea. Obscure electronics by Filmmaker, '80s post-punk by Killing Joke and synth-pop from Severed Heads tell us a little bit more about these pioneers. Dee Diggs FACT Mix 710 New York's Dee Diggs is on a quest to remind everyone that dance music is black music. Her FACT mix is her fiery mission statement, cutting through the history of black dance music, from Paris Is Burning and vintage acts like DJ Deeon and Karizma to NYC's new guard, including upstarts like Devoye and AceMo. This mix is classic, soulful and banging in all the right places, securing Diggs' own place in the canon she's charting. Eris Drew Raving Disco Breaks Vol. 1 On this year's funkiest mixtape, Eris Drew made some of dance music's most classic sounds her own. Raving Disco Breaks is composed of dance classics chopped into breaks on-the-fly by the American DJ, showcasing not only her impressive technical skills but also the emotional, spiritual and often nostalgic flair that makes her sets so electrifying. It's old-school technique with a new-school vibe. Francesco Del Garda Robert Johnson Archive 0002 Francesco Del Garda played this set at Robert Johnson on the banks of the Rhine a few days after Christmas last year. He couldn't have asked for a better setting: sun rising, perfect soundsystem, six-hour time slot, festive crowd. This recording, an edition of the Frankfurt club's new mix series, gives us only an hour of it, but it shows Del Garda on fire, indulging the uplifting sound that distinguishes him from his contemporaries. Batu Truancy Volume 240 Batu describes his Truancy mix as the closing set for a "festival in 2030 called Bristol-Bass." Given his Timedance label and his own inventive productions, he's in a good position to imagine the future of UK dance music. The mix’s backbone wiggles and booms with modern bass music, while making adventurous jumps from Latin and Afro-Caribbean rhythms to ambient techno and experimental club. Erika IT.podcast.s08e01 Erika's Interdimensional Transmissions podcast from March really lives up to the Detroit label's name: it sounds like you're hearing an actual transmission from another dimension. IT does down-the-rabbithole techno better than anyone, and this recording of Erika at an LA showcase for sister label Eye Teeth shows the sound at its cosmic, funky, head-spinning best. DJ Persuasion Dedicated To The Dedicated 94-95 Ask any junglist worth their salt: 1994 and '95 were the golden years. Disagree? Well, you might feel differently after listening to Dedicated To The Dedicated 94-95, the latest hour-long mix by '90s dance music fanatic DJ Persuasion, AKA Semtek. Every tune, most of them near-impossible to track down, writhes with rhythm and soul. The warm basslines and time-stretched vocals spark tingles of euphoria. When people say the '90s were better, this is the kind of thing they're thinking of. Sherelle LDN: Bass & Percs Special Earlier this year, Sherelle's debut Boiler Room session—a whirlwind of footwork, jungle and grime—went viral. While it's easy for some high BPM DJs to tire out their audience, her set maintains an addictive high energy throughout, with explosive, playful transitions that sparked the dance music equivalent of a mosh pit. Wait for the gutsy rewind at 23:40 that shot her to instant (and deserved) fame. Leif Freerotation 2019 Leif is part of a small group of DJs whose yearly sets at Freerotation festival in Wales always feel like a big deal. 2019 was no exception. In this recording, Leif redefines the peak-time set, starting slow and spindly before moving gracefully through many shades of cosy, rhythmic club music. There are tunes by Equiknoxx and Domu, Efdemin and Aphex Twin, all stitched together with extraordinary skill. As one SoundCloud commenter put it: "are you even human." Dr. Rubinstein Phonica Mix Series 56 Dr. Rubinstein is like an acid historian, wading through decades of dance music history to find the best 303 lines ever put to wax. Yet she still finds time in her Phonica mix to highlight several up-and-coming talents (Jack Roland, Gian) alongside more familiar names (DMX Krew, Adapta). Sometimes dark, sometimes bright, Phonica Mix Series 56 was a deeply psychedelic trip, weaving excellent electro and techno between forgotten acid bombs. As always with Rubinstein, the mixing was world-class, each transition bringing us further into her unique sound world. Leon Vynehall DJ-Kicks Last year, Leon Vynehall released Nothing Is Still, showing the world that his production chops extended way beyond the club. In 2019 he did something similar, but with DJing. His proof this time is a spellbinding DJ-Kicks mix, which blends genres, eras and moods together with sublime flow and dexterity. Dancehall, techno, pop, jungle, soul, a solo piano piece—what could've been a hot mess ends up as one of the classiest mix CDs in recent memory. re:ni Dekmantel Podcast 253 re:ni's Dekmantel podcast does everything right. The tracklist left the sleuths at mixesdb mostly stumped. The mixing is inspired, moving swiftly through tempos and styles with quick sleights of hand and extended blends. More than anything, though, its re:ni's ineffable sense of groove—slinky, fluid, always in flux—that makes this one really pop off. Turtle Bugg HNYPOT 330: African Art of Acid (Triple A Baybee) Mixx Turtle Bugg's Honey Soundsystem mix makes a point so simple it often goes unsaid: black people invented acid house. And yet, as he puts it, "There was no Second Summer Of Love in Amerikkka, no Ibiza for Negroes to spend their holiday, no beginnings of a multi-million dollar industry that could change the lives of Lady Liberty's bastard children." The voices of Dave Chappelle, Malcolm X and Derrick May ring out over interlocking acid lines. The message is clear: black ingenuity thrives, no matter who is paying attention. Ben UFO Hessle Audio - 9th September 2019 What makes this Hessle Audio show, one of many hosted by Ben UFO in 2019, so special? Well, it just is. On that early autumn night, armed with a stack of fresh wax, the UK DJ was on particularly impressive form, treating regulars and first-timer listeners to a beautifully woven tapestry of ambient, Afro techno, jungle and Joe. When it aired, it wasn't just nerds and ravers listening, either—Four Tet, Hunee, John Talabot and other dance music dons had all tuned in for their weekly dose of musical inspiration. Via App Crack Mix 307 Via App taps into the elemental energy of Brooklyn's techno underground on this mix for Crack, a set as volatile as any of their recent productions. This bumpy ride through jarring turns and interruptions, with its snarling, punkish spirit, hit harder than most other mixes we heard this year. Powder In Space by Powder Powder Powder In Space You play Powder In Space once. You think, "This is nice." You leave it for a while, then play it a second and third time. You notice things like the Roy Brooks vocal, or Daphne's bubbling vibraphone melody, that you didn't catch the first time. You also realize you've fallen in love with it. This is how Powder's mix gets under your skin: her unobtrusive approach, drawn from offbeat house with gorgeous textures, waits for you to come around to it. Shannen SP DISCWOMAN 80 Alongside Kode9, Shannen SP runs Hyperdub's Ø events at London's Corsica Studios, a wonderful monthly midweek showcase of experimental music and art. She's quickly become a DJ to watch, and this mix for Discwoman showcases her knack for linking together sharp, angular beats with loose percussive rhythms—a style she sums up as "witchy black energy." Ciel FACT Mix 724 Cindy Li's FACT mix has a specific concept: "fast & light," inspired by hummingbirds. It also captures what makes her DJing so dynamic. The Toronto artist makes breakbeat, electro and techno float like feathers on the breeze, moving through quick-footed drum patterns and fluttering melodies with finesse. Her technique changes the feel of the music itself, which is among the highest compliments you can pay a DJ. Physical Therapy Live: Honcho Campout 2019 The Way In may have had the freakiest sounds at this year's Honcho Campout. Hours before CCL brought the dance floor to tears with Beat Happening, Physical Therapy unfurled this masterclass in trippy eclecticism. Cuts of perfectly dreamy drum & bass, a slo-mo version of Cece Peniston's "Finally" layered over Stenny’s "Stress Test," Andrew Weatherall's remix of St Etienne, D'Angelo's "Devil's Pie"—the highlights in this one are simply too many to name. From a punter's perspective, hearing a DJ with such unique style going for it like this is basically as good as it gets. Josey Rebelle Essential Mix "The thread that runs through the music I play, and my whole life, comes from my parent's generation," Josey Rebelle told us in 2017's Real Scenes: London film. Her parents are part of the Windrush generation, which arrived in the UK from the Caribbean in the 1950s and went on to make an inestimable impact on British life and culture. Rebelle's heritage pours out the speakers every time she's behind the decks. She's a quintessential London DJ: informed by the city's record shop and soundsystem culture, she's comfortable weaving together soul, techno, house, disco, R&B and jungle. Her first Essential Mix was dark and funky, with deep US music from Jamal Moss and Aybee featuring alongside London favourites Steven Julien and Cooly G. Ariel Zetina Truancy Volume 249 "Power to them sexy transsexuals out there, transforming the world," a woman intones in the opening moments of Ariel Zetina’s Truancy mix. It's one of many vivid vocal samples that contribute to the smartbar resident's sense of narrative. Beneath them, trippy acid house and soulful techno—much of it produced by other queer and trans artists—paint different moods. Sometimes it's raw and sexy, other times meditative and strange, but always charged with attitude and passion. Jackie House HNYPOT 300: Half A Bar Will Do It Jackie House's "Half A Bar Will Do It" mix came out 11 months ago, in that post-New Year's, deep-winter stretch of time when dance music in the Northern Hemisphere briefly goes into hibernation. It matches that mood perfectly, easing, over the course of three hours, through soothing, low-energy grooves of all kinds, from Kompakt deep cuts to ambient jungle pitched way, way down. Jackie's photo—swaddled in blankets, bathed in warm lamplight—shows the best way to take this one in. Nosedrip Live: Dekmantel Festival 2019 It's one thing to play a bunch of psychedelic dub and obscure post-punk on the radio. It's something else entirely to mix it at a festival and hold the dance floor. That's what Nosedrip did on the Red Light Radio stage at Dekmantel this summer. Luckily, we now have the recording to pogo to. In the STROOM head's hands, a rare Belgian cut like Siglo XX's "Individuality" becomes a statement of purpose: "I don't wanna be like the others / I am an originality / In search for individuality." Sybil Jason Blowing Up The Workshop 103 Sybil Jason's Blowing Up The Workshop mix is only 40 minutes long and it ends abruptly after a particularly satisfying transition. Showcasing her range, this quick, intense and blindsiding mix ranges from weirdo downtempo to synth-pop to techno, as Jason jumps between eras like a skilled time traveler. She had a bigger year than ever in 2019, and it's DJing skills like this that got her there. Spekki Webu Nous'klaer Radio #20 Though trance has been bubbling up again in dance music for a few years now, in 2019 it took centre-stage. While some turned to Eurodance for inspiration, Spekki Webu sought out the throb of the genre's earlier psychedelic forms. This precise set for Nous'klaer Audio is a masterclass in otherworldly DJing, journeying into hallucinogenic, hypnagogic soundscapes before it melts into the ether.

Eris Drew
Raving Disco Breaks Vol. 1

On this year's funkiest mixtape, Eris Drew made some of dance music's most classic sounds her own. Raving Disco Breaks is composed of dance classics chopped into breaks on-the-fly by the American DJ, showcasing not only her impressive technical skills but also the emotional, spiritual and often nostalgic flair that makes her sets so electrifying. It's old-school technique with a new-school vibe.

Leon Vynehall
DJ-Kicks

Last year, Leon Vynehall released Nothing Is Still, showing the world that his production chops extended way beyond the club. In 2019 he did something similar, but with DJing. His proof this time is a spellbinding DJ-Kicks mix, which blends genres, eras and moods together with sublime flow and dexterity. Dancehall, techno, pop, jungle, soul, a solo piano piece—what could've been a hot mess ends up as one of the classiest mix CDs in recent memory.

Physical Therapy
Live: Honcho Campout 2019

The Way In may have had the freakiest sounds at this year's Honcho Campout. Hours before CCL brought the dance floor to tears with Beat Happening, Physical Therapy unfurled this masterclass in trippy eclecticism. Cuts of perfectly dreamy drum & bass, a slo-mo version of Cece Peniston's "Finally" layered over Stenny’s "Stress Test," Andrew Weatherall's remix of St Etienne, D'Angelo's "Devil's Pie"—the highlights in this one are simply too many to name. From a punter's perspective, hearing a DJ with such unique style going for it like this is basically as good as it gets.

items.text: Yu Su Little Birds, Moonbath feat. Michelle Helene Mackenzie   Second Circle
items.description: Tring! There's a lot to say about "Little Birds, Moonbath," the enchanting new age track by Yu Su, but that sound (an alert string chord struck at a very high, slightly off-key pitch) is its distinguishing feature. It might be usefully compared to a sharp nudge from a friend ("Pay attention!") in the presence of something worth seeing, or in this case hearing. Those sounds are Michelle Helene Mackenzie's lace-like modular synth, the bucolic cascades of melody, and Yu Su's poetic, deep-in-the-mix spoken word. Where most ambient tracks aspire to emulate nature, "Little Birds, Moonbath" seems like an idealised vision of it.

Listening to DJ Python's music feels like floating. It's soothing and a little whimsical, plus there's a depth of texture that gently hints at something more intense. On Derretirse, Brian Pineyro presents the dreamiest version of his characteristic deep reggaeton sound. Wavy opener "Lampara" is perfectly placed, welcoming you in pulses of glimmering synths and soft, slow drums. It eases into the more moving tracks on the record while also being a comforting moment to hang out in. "Lampara" puts the "warm" in warm up.

For a producer whose catalogue includes tracks built around a "seasick carnival organ," robotic meta-commentary and, of course, a "Claptrap," the title cut off Joe's Comeme debut felt relatively straightforward. Well, at least until you notice the track's tension stems from a 7/8 rhythm and dizzying syncopation. Like the best records in Joe's discography, this one makes you wonder, "How exactly did he come up with that?"

items.text: Liquid Earth Origins Of Telluria TerraFirm
items.description: In the past few years, tech house has had a quiet renaissance. Liquid Earth, or Urulu, one of several producers rescuing the style from Beatport chuggagedon, has released a few of its most intriguing tracks this year. With its wiggly acid bassline and tweaked-out effects (best summed up as "crickets in outer space"), "Origins Of Telluria" echoes the OG Croydon style of tech house in its rolling, even-tempered arrangement. In the track's last quarter, some regal synth chords add a dash of high-tech soul to this trippy A-side.

items.text: Whodat & Viola Klein Funeral Song  Workshop
items.description: The frequent tempo changes in Whodat & Viola Klein's oddball house jam "Funeral Song" gave some DJs headaches. Luckily, its sunny, laid-back feel was perfectly suited to the early stages of a party, when crowds are still finding their feet. Anyway, who cares about a clang or two when you're treating the dance floor to the best Workshop track in years?

items.text: LOFT That Hyde Trakk  Tri Angle
items.description: Jungle sounded futuristic in the early '90s. Why are so many new artists obsessed with sounding like the old ones? "That Hyde Trakk" is jungle that feels new, and a track that LOFT (now known as AYA) has been working towards her entire career. The sounds are sleek, the rhythm changes brain-scrambling, the speed blinding. It's enough to make you astounded, perhaps like a new listener back in the old days.

items.text: Amazondotcom A Flower, Nocturnal And Permanent   Subreal
items.description: For a quick track, "A Flower, Nocturnal And Permanent" feels surprisingly at ease. Amazondotcom paces manipulated samples of birds chirping, leaves rustling and crowds muttering with blunt, jangly percussion and soft wobbles to let the space between the elements set the tone. Still, the pulse is more than persuasive enough to make dance floors move.

Philly-based artist DJ Haram makes music at the nexus of East Coast club and traditional Arab sounds. "No Idol" is the introductory track to her most recent EP, Grace. The track is a playful, extended dialogue between minimalist samples, from a stuttering flute trill to more dramatic sounds, like the weighty orchestral chorus that floods in halfway through.

Some of the freshest club music of 2019 came either from East Asia or East Africa, served up by labels like SVBKVLT, Hakuna Kulala and Nyege Nyege Tapes. One EP, a collaboration between Nairobi's Slikback and Shanghai's Hyph11E, was a product of both. The standout cut on Slip B was "ISHU," a fireball of manic rhythms, industrial noise and sudden stop-starts. Loud and ferocious, it's the sound of dance music's bleeding edge.

"There's only one winner in this bitch and I win everything," Shygirl snarls on "BB"'s closest thing to a chorus. It's hard not to believe her. Produced by Sega Bodega, this electrifying club beat comes alive with Shygirl's boastful MCing, the catchiest monotone we heard all year.

At first glance, "Claustro" was another garage cut with R&B samples. Same old, same old, right? Wrong. This sizzler was a departure from the Londoner's typically mournful sound: pacier, brighter, more propulsive. And how about that finale? With 30 seconds to go, he performed a hard left turn into Eurodance melodies and chipmunk vocals. Only Burial could deliver two bangers in one track.

Despite his brilliant track record, you might not have expected a techno-oriented producer like Stenny to supply 2019's most robust UK garage experiment. Like many new 2-step productions, "Stress Test" plays directly from the dark and minimal El-B playbook, but it's delivered with the fresh enthusiasm of a garage dilettante. While it ditches garage's bubbly effervescence for a more stone-faced delivery, its firm execution stands out.

items.text: Alec Falconer Cab Sauve (Harry Wills Sour Grapes Dub)   Entity London
items.description: Of the various factions comprising UK garage's new wave, Harry Wills, Alec Falconer and co. are the psychedelic minimalists. By emphasising the style's loose-limbed swerve and restraining its lairy tendencies, productions like Wills' "Cab Suave" remix make a snug fit with trippy house and stripped-back techno. There's a hint of minimal's jerky oddness in the mix, too. The play of organ, stab and synth recalls both Perlon and Groove Chronicles, a key trait distinguishing this school's brand of garage from the crowd.

Instinct, a side project from the UK producer Burnski, embodies a sound that's crept to the fore these past few years: deep club cuts at the crossroads of minimal, tech house and garage. The series has had lots of great moments, but its high water mark so far is "Pistolwhip," a floor-filler with the sinister air of druggy minimal but a stepping rhythm and vocal hook that are pure UKG. No wonder this sleeper hit was a DJ favorite all year.

The excellent label (and clothing brand) Dr Banana releases classic UKG along with new stuff, and while some old tunes inevitably steal the show (last year's "Romantic Call"), the current artists on their records really hold their own. On Dr Banana 07, new tracks from Holloway and ZeroFG outshone old ones from Sky Joose and DJ Texta, especially ZeroFG's "Renegade Steppa." Dark and trippy with an evil bassline, this one feels fresh in a way only new music can.

Tracks by Kieran Hebden have been soundtracking summers for more than a decade. Where 2019's other Four Tet hit, "Only Human," harnessed the power of a well-chosen vocal sample, "Dreamer" is all about shimmering textures and shuffling percussion. At just three minutes long, this was tough to work into DJ sets, but that didn't stop "Dreamer" becoming one of the most popular tunes of the year. Another summer, another Four Tet smash.

items.text: Peggy Gou Starry Night  Gudu Records
items.description: Peggy Gou couldn't have set the scene for this tune more clearly. "Starry Night," a wavy piano house tune flecked with acid lines and vocals mulling the fleeting nature of popularity, is lush and inviting like a humid evening breeze. As slick as shimmery house comes (with a dazzling video to match), it funnels all of Gou's strengths into one radiant package.

Remember Peter Bjorn And John's "Young Folks," the indie pop smash with that insanely hummable melody? "Fury's Laughter," by Samuel André Madsen, might be the house music equivalent. Its whistling earworm was catnip to sun-drenched dance floors in 2019, a tune so catchy 76,000 ravers felt compelled to whip out Shazam. (Context: those are incredible numbers for an underground house track.) Could this be the record that finally catapults one of dance music's unsung heroes into the spotlight?

items.text: Marie Davidson Work It (Soulwax Remix)  Ninja Tune
items.description: This time 13 years ago, dancers were jumping around to Simian Mobile Disco's "Hustler," a track with a deadpan vocal that helped define the blog house era of the '00s. The "Hustler" for summer 2019 was Soulwax's remix of Marie Davidson's "Work It," which resurrected last year's most addictive vocal for a jacking, high-energy bomb that lit up festivals big and small. As they've done so many times before, Soulwax made a hit track even bigger.

items.text: Nathan Micay The Party We Could Have  LuckyMe
items.description: Plenty of artists made and played trance this year, but few did it with the passion of Nathan Micay. "The Party We Could Have" is the kind of out-and-out late-'90s worship we've been waiting for him to make all along. It so unabashedly goes for it (listen to those belching basslines) that it could put a smile on even the most ardent trance-hater's face, becoming an explosive summit hit through bliss, and sheer force.

items.text: Aurora Halal Eternal Blue (Wata Igarashi Crossing Remix)  Mutual Dreaming Records
items.description: Aurora Halal once described a formative techno experience with terms like "clarity of sound," "3D spectrum of frequencies" and "high-definition psychedelic emersion." That's pretty much what you get on Wata Igarashi's remix of her track "Eternal Blue." All dizzying arpeggios and impossibly crystalline sounds, touched with that sense of cosmic drama Igarashi does so well, it's the kind of techno that calls to mind the expanding brain meme, and that, on the right soundsystem, could give you a proper out-of-body experience.

items.text: Rosa Anschütz Rigid (Kobosil 44 Rush Mix)  R - Label Group
items.description: A push-and-pull between light and dark, happy and sad, is central to plenty of great music. Kobosil's "44 Rush Mix" of Rosa Anschütz's "Rigid" found a perfect ratio between different moods, pairing pained, droning vocals with a thundering techno instrumental that, at times, feels euphoric. The result was one of the most powerful techno tracks of 2019, and a high point in Kobosil's career.

items.text: Paula Temple Joshua And Goliath (Techno Version)  Noise Manifesto
items.description: Techno doesn't get many anthems, but "Joshua And Goliath" was one of 2019's. The sonic equivalent of a wrecking ball smashing through a burnt-out warehouse, Paula Temple's peak-time bomb still manages to feel musical, a churning chorus of synths with plenty of moving parts. Not every techno DJ was brave enough to unleash it on a crowd, but those who did sent dance floors into meltdown.

Love gnarly techno? How about EBM? Two yeses? Then this was your year. One of the stars in this camp was VTSS, the Berlin-based Pole whose no-nonsense DJ sets took her to new and far-flung places in 2019. Her productions helped, too, namely "Fruition," a stormy banger with craggy textures and gruesome artwork. But beneath the murk there was something else: a beautiful melody as wispy and delicate as frost.

items.text: Varg A Weak Heart To Break (BD 4-Ever)  Northern Electronics
items.description: "It's funny because I have a bunch of techno bangers that I keep making, but it's not really what I like to present," Varg told RA this year. "A Weak Heart To Break (BD 4-Ever)" is the highlight from two EPs of straight-up techno bangers, bundling Varg's contradictions into one trance-tinged steamroller. It's hard not to be taken by its melodies, an outpouring of emotion that makes Varg's music so universal.

items.text: Off The Meds Belter (Joy O Belly Mix)  Studio Barnhus
items.description: "Confident will be playing this in 20 years," tweeted Ben UFO of Joy O's "Belly Mix" of "Belter." What might make it so replayable? That could be closely tied to the much-discussed decline of dance floor anthems. If our collective appetite for bright, hooky hits (Joy O's "Ellipsis" being one) has waned, then "Belly Mix" is one possible mutation: the don't-feel-good track. Where Off The Meds' Kamohelo Khoaripe seems like the story's enigmatic anti-hero, Joy O's sour bassline is the seedy antagonist.

items.text: Kosh Keep Hope Alive  Casa Voyager
items.description: DJs love Casa Voyager, the Moroccan house, techno and electro label named after a train station, because of tracks like Kosh's "Keep Hope Alive." Fat, spacey and emotional, this rolling house track is best played sometime deep into the night, its bubbling bassline preparing the dance floor for lift-off into outer space.

For the last few years, Deniro's techno records for labels like Trip and Tape Records have skewed towards the left-of-centre. "Monsoon 2," a percussive techno track, was more understated. It's shuffling percussion was built for classy DJ sets, rolling with the easygoing bounce of classic techno. This wasn't the flashiest techno track of the year, but it was one of the slickest.

items.text: Karima F Random Loop From Doepfer Site  Schloss
items.description: The Norwegian producer Karima F's breakout track is all about patience. It starts out as a simple breakbeat loop, building slowly before an organ loop locks the groove into place. It's not so much a drop as a gear shift, one that could give a set a jolt of energy. It's the rare track that finds an anthemic quality in restraint, simmering below boiling point while its melody wriggles into your head.

items.text: CCL x Flora FM Liquify Interference Planet Euphorique
items.description: One of two collaborations from the Seattle-based artists this year (the other being "Winding Plod," which lives up to its name, off Bandcloud's excellent charity compilation), "Liquidity Interference" lands directly on the dance floor. The drums are crisp, and there's so much space you can almost hear each percussion hit. Then melodic synths soar overhead, bringing a lightness to those hours when the music has taken over control of your movement.

Leila Samir's  No Music EP was a shining debut that immediately garnered approval from the likes of Andrew Weatherall and Zaltan. The first single, "Anxiety" snipped elements of Saudi Arabian music, techno and hard drum to produce something scornful and foreboding. Leading with unassuming synths, it isn't long before it descends into a rapidly intensifying rhythm.

Air Max '97 has coined an apt term for his bludgeoning genre of music: "horror dance." "Bruxis" is a great example of this off-kilter style, incorporating squalls of slashing knives, a mischievous horror film soundtrack melody and extraterrestrial vocals. But Air Max '97 isn't about cheap thrills. At one point, he delivers a perfectly timed, suspenseful break. After the mayhem, it feels well deserved.

On "Peninsula," the Club Chai cofounder Lara Sarkissian evokes an epic scene. It's a grey morning on an ancient battlefield, and thunderous hand drumming is calling troops to war. A sense of mystery builds as metallic groans and eerie duduk, an Armenian woodwind, slither through the complex rhythms. But the percussion's controlled intensity never falters, resulting in a strange but powerful experimental club bomb.

In 2019, Version moved on from the reduced dubstep it does so well for more adventurous explorations of rhythm. And who better for this than Sheffield's finest beat twister, Yak? "Kaepora," the B-side on Version 013, is the German label's most striking track yet, and perhaps Yak's as well. A mirage of sun-dappled vocals and shimmering drums set to a nonstandard 115-BPM rhythm, it is utterly unconventional, but so lush and groovy you might not notice.

items.text: DJ Plead Salt And Pepper Nervous Horizon
items.description: DJ Plead's music is rooted in Lebanese and Syrian music traditions, along with UK house and bass. "Salt And Pepper" is an experimental take on Arab beats, complete with the soulfulness of the best UK funky. With frenetic, looping percussion and searing synths, this is DJ Plead's most compelling track this year.

Paul Woolford's "VORTEX" originals were all about the primitive thrill of a slowly rising tone. Sully's remix succeeds by taking a harder route, doing away with Woolford's ultra-effective motif in favour of a specific idea. He focusses on turning breakbeats into pitched, melodic material, twisting drums into razor-sharp tonal swords that slice and dice with the best of the '94 school.

items.text: Galaxian Coming Up For Air  Ilian Tape
items.description: Galaxian is synonymous with electro, but his standout work of 2019 recalls vintage Christoph De Babalon. This is a war of the worlds, where apocalyptic despair faces off with dead-eyed violence, but a furtive glimmer of hope watches on. Juggernaut hoover, tortured, pulverised breaks and awe-inspiring pads don't just tug at the heartstrings, they rip them clean off. But for all its horror, "Coming Up For Air"'s true power resides in that it's ultimately a redemptive experience. Its confronting emotional honesty disturbs but purifies.

items.text: Djrum Hard To Say R&S Records
items.description: Djrum's sound is a high-wire balancing act between high intensity and big emotions. When the two are properly poised, the results inspire a hypersensorial awe. "Hard To Say," which Djrum cheekily described as "ambient gabber," might represent the pinnacle of this high-risk, high-reward approach. The grizzly distortion that usually accompanies 909 kicks at 150+ BPM speeds is counterpoised by a milky, post-dubstep ambience. Djrum's nosebleed drums and emulsifying atmosphere combine with transcendent force.

items.text: Double 99 Ripgroove (Fixate Remix) Ice Cream Records
items.description: It was the rewind heard round the world. The track? A rowdy edit of a rowdy UK garage tune that seemed to possess Sherelle, whose performance went viral and rocketed her to fame. On its own, "Ripgroove" is a force. But Fixate, somehow, makes it harder with an edit that combines speed garage and jungle. It's the kind of hybridism that's made him one of the scene's more exciting producers. Thankfully, Ice Cream Records came out of retirement to release his version officially.

items.text: Homemade Weapons Svalsat (Donato Dozzy Remix)  Samurai Music
items.description: Donato Dozzy has played drum & bass in DJ sets for a few years now, but this earthshaking remix of Homemade Weapons marks his first venture into the genre as a producer. Enmeshing the original's foreboding drones and breathless gasps in a web of spiralling rhythms, Dozzy's signature control of tension and release summons a force of tectonic pressure. This is drum & bass made with a techno philosophy, resulting in a lethal roller with an unstoppable momentum.

items.text: Afrodeutsche I Know Not What I Do  River Rapid
items.description: This year, Afrodeutsche emerged as one of dance music's most exciting newcomers. That's thanks to tracks like "I Know Not What I Do." Deep and spacey, this techno-electro hybrid was one of the trippiest tracks of 2019, a low-slung groover perfect for DJ play long after peak-time. Loopy and subtle, it dazzled clubbers all over the world.

"Moloko" was yet another excellent transmission from Cabaret Recordings, a label that specialises in spacey, subtle sounds. Pitched somewhere between techno and house, Eris's second official release featured three solid tracks, but "Moloko" was best of all. Its rolling groove and humming bassline were built for DJs spinning to afterhours crowds, the kind of tune that convinces everyone to stay a little bit longer.

items.text: Gene On Earth Lunchbox Music Limousine Dream
items.description: When a digging veteran like DJ Koolt plays "Lunchbox Music," clubbers might be shocked, then pleased, to learn it came out in 2019. Many of Gene On Earth's contemporaries are trying to give their productions just this type of magic, but they rarely sound so much like a bonafide classic.

items.text: Stanislav Tolkachev When I Was A Boy  Semantica Records
items.description: Stanislav Tolkachev possesses techno's most recognisable style, but he still finds ways to surprise us. This year, that surprise came in the form of "When I Was A Boy," a rare instance of the Ukrainian maestro using anything close to a conventional melody. That melody what made "When I Was A Boy" a perfect option for late-hour DJ sets, where its ambiguous mood was entrancing.

items.text: Mor Elian Radical Spectacular  Fever AM
items.description: What makes a great afterhours track? In other words, which music works best for tired legs and addled minds? Dainty melodies usually go down a treat, especially when they dance with the ease and flair of a Bolshoi ballerina. This describes the centrepiece of Mor Elian's "Radical Spectacular," a sunrise track with dynamic drums and bags of joie de vivre. Love Oni Ayhun's timeless classic? Then this one's for you.

items.text: Carl Gari & Abdullah Miniawy Zawaj  Whities
items.description: For "Zawaj," the German trio Carl Gari laid down what might be the most desolate soundscape of the year. The Arabic vocals, sung by Abdullah Miniawy over its over its haunting tones, were just as powerful. The abstract poem, delivered in Miniawy's mother tongue, captured the beauty of Arabic, a language claiming its place in electronic music.

items.text: Ghostride The Drift Untitled B3  XPQ?
items.description: For the shadow network of ambient producers stretching from Moscow to Berlin, Philadelphia to Tokyo, the artists Exael, uon and Huerco S are key connectors. Due to locality, these nodes mostly communicate online, but Ghostride The Drift happened when those three got in the same room. "Untitled (B3)" is a slurry of ambient, textural improv, dub techno and IDM experimentation that feels like it could have been made in 1994, the present, or some far-off future.

items.text: Kali Malone Sacrificial Code  iDEAL Recordings
items.description: It's appropriate that Kali Malone's organ dirge lands in this section. The American musician relocated to Sweden eight years ago, attracted to the country's improvised music scene. "I noticed that it was very careful and considerate of the other musicians," she said. "And it inspired a different sort of listening in me." On her second album of durational organ music, Malone adopts the language of liturgy ("sacrifice," "glory" and "worship") but her ritual involves adhering to strict, harmonic rules. On tracks like "Sacrificial Code," this discipline results in transcendence.

items.text: Ana Roxanne It's A Rainy Day On The Cosmic Shore  Leaving Records
items.description: Ana Roxanne's debut EP, ~~~, felt more like a private audio diary than a calculated unveiling, and with good reason. Recorded in 2015, ~~~'s uncanny mix of new age, ambient and R&B went practically unheard until finding its way to the Leaving Records cofounder Matthewdavid. "It's A Rainy Day On The Cosmic Shore" combines field recordings of waves with loops and drones coaxed from a vintage Moog Synthesizer IIIP. In the Californian artist's hands, simple gestures feel magical.

items.text: Félicia Atkinson Moderato Cantabile  Shelter Press
items.description: The first track on Félicia Atkinson's The Flower And The Vessel is just bare whispering over silence. The second, "Moderato Cantabile," rouses the album's musical environment. It begins with a distant crystal tone, gently discovering new layers of sound and texture, with piano parts and organic samples floating through. Sinking in feels sedating, intimate and a bit wistful, a portal into the French avant-garde artist's quiet sound world.

items.text: James Massiah Natural Born Killers (Ride For Me)  Levels
items.description: The London poet James Massiah's debut EP came with the visual of the year. The Ian Pons Jewell-directed clip depicts a surreal scorcher in Buenos Aires, which is somewhat ironic, as "Ride For Me" sounds unmistakably like London. It captures the roll and swagger of the British capital, finding an easy middle-ground between early Chicago house and eski. Just as Massiah's poetry often relies on the inflection of his voice, "Ride For Me"'s addictive quality hinges on his relaxed, confident delivery.

LSDXOXO is a wizard when it comes to edits, and his version of SOPHIE's "Faceshopping" might be his crown jewel. Out of all his tracks, this was the one you heard the most this year, which comes down to its simplicity: the vocal is flattened out into a hypnotic hook, and the track gallops along with the grace of classic techno. There are no bells and whistles, just a new-school attitude and an old-school spirit.

items.text: AceMo Where They At ? ? ? feat. John FM  Self-released
items.description: The most played track off AceMo's All My Life EP is the infectious "Where They At ? ? ?" The simple, recognizable synth line from Robin S. 's "Show Me Love" is given a modern thrust with the help of AceMo's lo-fi synths and John FM's catchy vocals, which shout out girls from the "self-made" to the "brown berets." Soulful with a political edge, this dominated New York's clubs this year.

items.text: Octo Octa Can You See Me?  T4T LUV NRG
items.description: Octo Octa knows a simple line of reassurance can mean the world. Given her experience as a trans woman, you can't help but feel the vocal on "Can You See Me?" is meant to soothe oppressed peoples' silent pain, especially those rendered structurally invisible. "I know exactly how you feel!," the track's single line repeats. Soaring over a wistful house jam, it's a comforting message.

items.text: Loraine James For You And I  Hyperdub
items.description:
For You And I was born in the daydream of a girl gazing out the window of the estate tower on its cover. As Loraine James recently told Pitchfork, her Hyperdub debut is an intensely personal album, exploring the forces, good and bad, that shape her existence as a queer black woman in London. Jagged and smooth, anxious and romantic, swiftly skating through glitch, ambient and grime, it's as fresh and addictive as anything the London label's put out for years.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: DJ Nigga Fox Cartas Na Manga  Príncipe
items.description:
On Cartas Na Manga, the wild energy that ran through Rogério Brandão's trailblazing records for Príncipe and Warp was funnelled into something darker and woozier. Tracks like "Água Morna" presented a slower take on Brandão's trademark batida-inspired rhythms, while "Sub Zero" and "Nhama" plunged deeper into the Angolan-born, Lisbon-based artist's exceptional percussion toolkit. With Afrodiasporic sounds shaking clubs and festivals everywhere from Los Angeles to Kampala, Cartas Na Manga marked Brandão as a leading light for this global community. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

On New Atlantis, Efdemin achieved a subtle landmark, merging the experimental impulses of the records he makes as Phillip Sollmann with the sublime melodic techno he's built his name on. Fantastical instruments like the "sing-drum" waft in and out of the mix, giving the album an otherworldly feel befitting its inspiration, an unfinished 17th-century work of utopic fiction. New Atlantis was Efdemin's first album for Ostgut Ton, and it played a crucial part in the Berghain-affiliated label's extraordinary year.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Coil The Gay Man's Guide To Safer Sex +2  Musique Pour La Danse
items.description:
Coil are best-known for occult experiments in electronic music, but this brilliant reissue from Musique Pour La Danse captures a lesser-known side of the English: their early '90s flirtation with dance music. What was originally written to soundtrack an educational film about gay sex from 1992 ended up becoming one of 2019's unlikeliest hits, and no wonder—the New Age sheen, Balearic tempo and trippy vocal hooks make each of these songs irresistible. A lush introduction to one of electronic music's most important bands. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Spotify / Soundcloud

7 Directions feels at once ancient and futuristic. Nkisi's rhythms tap into the eternal beat of Congolese percussion music but the aesthetic presentation is hypermodern. There are also retrofuturisms in the mix, too—her pads often recall the stargazing drama of Detroit techno, while the white-knuckled intensity of hardcore bristles beneath the surface. For all its time- and space-spanning richness, the execution is powerfully spartan, making this an economical but profound world-building experience. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Various 30 Years Of Rage Part 1 & 2  Above Board Projects
items.description:
30 Years Of Rage, a four-part compilation by Fabio and Grooverider, is the story of how jungle came to be. The London club night's music policy was far from a straight line through the "hardcore continuum"—besides the conveyor belt of British post-acid-house records, the compilation includes Plus 8 anthems, Frankie Bones breakbeats and, as Joe Muggs wrote, "off-its-tits sunrise house." The set shows not only the fertile conditions for jungle's emergence, but that it took Fabio and Grooverider's imaginative DJing to bring it to life. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Spotify

If Anthony Naples' last album was made for low-key afterparties, Fog FM rewinds (or fast-forwards) to a heaving dance floor. It's pitch-black and someone has been going OTT with the smoke machine. The tunes are detailed and twisted, full of strange melodies, zippy rhythms and slamming basslines. You feel disorientated yet at ease. Later in the night, the music softens to house. There's even some ambient. From open till close, you're completely lost in the music.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: Ossia Devil's Dance  Blackest Ever Black
items.description:
Devil's Dance was the year's best dub techno record. The form, though, was a radical departure from the Basic Channel school. Ossia's first album essentially reimagined the style as a rootsier product of Bristol rather than Berlin. What also set the album apart was its supernatural bent, a detached unreality comparable to films like Jacob's Ladder and Enter The Void. Whether on heavyweight thudders like "Hell Dub," the hall-of-mirrors sax of "Rubble" or the 23-minute driftathon "Vertigo," Devil's Dance evoked something like an out-of-body experience. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Octo Octa Resonant Body  T4T LUV NRG
items.description:
Each of Maya Bouldry-Morrison's albums mirrors her journey as a trans woman in a deeply personal way. Where her earlier records were moody and introverted, her third LP, Resonant Body, finds a new sense of empowerment. Released through T4T LUV NRG, the label she launched this year with her partner, Eris Drew, Resonant Body serves up vintage breaks and joyous house jams, further fueled by love-preaching vocals. As the artist said in an interview: "This record is different from my other ones, mostly because I'm just happier than I've been."

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

Getting talented musicians in a room and expecting great things to happen often leads to disappointment. The joy of 2, the second album by Lifted, is that it seems to have much humbler aspirations. The music, loosely inspired by ECM-style jazz, flows like a rambling, beers-round-the-sofa chat among friends, the instruments interplaying with a conversational rhythm. The players— Max D, Jeremy Hyman, Motion Graphics, Matt Papich—could have been a leftfield-house supergroup. But that wouldn't have been nearly as much fun. 

Listen: Bandcamp /  Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.text: E-Saggila My World My Way  Northern Electronics
items.description:
Techno, gabber, noise, breakcore, with the occasional metal shriek thrown in—whatever My World My Way is exactly, it's more DIY basement show than European nightclub. In fact, it makes most club music look woefully safe, which might explain how it landed on Northern Electronics, the label co-run by techno's enfant terrible, Varg. Awe-inducing in its power and chaos, My World My Way has an attitude you might wish was more common in electronic music. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Oli XL Rogue Intruder, Soul Enhancer  Bloom
items.description:
"I'm a loser baby, so why don't you kill me?" The line is borrowed from Beck's 1994 hit "Loser," but it sounds right at home on Oli XL's debut album, which is anxious, self-deprecating, funny and banging in equal measure. Homing in on a unique sound that combines the skip of UK garage and the autotuned lilt of modern hip-hop, the Swedish artist puts an irresistibly funky spin on bedroom pop. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Moor Mother Analog Fluids of Sonic Black Holes  Don Giovanni
items.description:
On her most striking album yet, Camae Ayewa weaves slave narratives, experimental jazz and negro spiritual samples into an end result that is equal parts haunting and empowering. Her knack for poetics and storytelling shines as she unfurls stories dispelling linear notions of time, intimately conveying the rage and anxiety of our political climate. On Analog Fluids Of Sonic Black Holes Ayewa channels this fury into a fiery call for mobilization, backed up with buzzing modular sounds that feel like they're carrying you through space and time. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: PTU Am I Who I Am  Trip
items.description:
It's never been easier to break the rules than it is today. But acts of creative rebellion can often sound unfocused or even immature. Am I Who I Am, from the Russian duo PTU, might at first seem like that sort of LP, but there's a loose philosophy that governs this mad record. PTU are residents of "techno's strange sector"—the album's strength is that this description feels like an understatement. But for all the LP's weirdo impulses (it's introduced by a cyborg reading 1984) what stood out most in PTU's uniquely odd world was a cheeky, Cheshire Cat charisma. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

For Pale Bloom, Sarah Davachi reduced her music down to its barest essence—classical solo piano—and then, one by one, carefully added hallmarks from her discography of otherworldly drone music. The LP gradually develops with swirls of organ, hums of string and quivering vocals, starting from nothing and growing into something intricate and complex. It's the most difficult, intense and rewarding album from an artist whose music rings loudest at its most quiet and tender.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

Sam Shepherd is the cleverest composer to emerge from UK dance music this decade. But Crush succeeds by tempering his studious impulses with a dash of raw energy. Written in just a few weeks, Crush shows Shepherd trusting his impulses. His cultivated take on harmony still dominates, but it feels all the richer alongside rough and tumble drum work. And unlike his debut album, Elaenia, it treats us to genuine Flo Po floor-fillers, too.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Bogdan Raczynski Rave 'Till You Cry  Disciples
items.description:
Bogdan Raczynski's madcap personality cloaks his music in absurdity. But beneath the hooligan trappings, Rave 'Till You Cry is disarmingly heartfelt and diaristic. These qualities aren't often associated with so-called braindance, which makes Raczynski's complex yet slapdash music oddly intimate. In today's professionalised dance music climate, wacky recluses like Raczynski come off like relics of authenticity. Rave 'Till You Cry then is a much-needed talisman for a spotlight-dodging artist who deserves all the attention he can get from new listeners discovering the Rephlex catalogue.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Boreal Massif We All Have An Impact  Pessimist Productions
items.description:
Climate change—we're fucked, right? Pessimist and Loop Faction, AKA Boreal Massif, certainly think so. Or do they? A sense of dread hangs heavy over their excellent debut album, We All Have An Impact, evoked via icy synths, leaden trip-hop beats and track titles like "The Brink Of Extinction." But it's not all doom and gloom. Some of the LP's best moments, like the frayed guitar on "Angel Of Dub," are tender and delicate. A sliver of hope, perhaps.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Oil Of Even Pearl’s Un-Insides Remix Album SOPHIE  Self-released
items.description:
SOPHIE's remix album is predictably iconoclastic. Technically, it's not so much a remix album as a two-part mix made entirely of her own remixes of her own tracks. It's available only on YouTube, or, naturally, with a limited-edition clutch bag. It's also wall-to-wall heat, transforming the subversive pop of her debut album into killer house and techno, bringing SOPHIE back to the dance floors where she first came to prominence. 

Listen: Spotify

items.text: The Caretaker Everywhere At The End Of Time (Stage 6)  History Always Favours The Winners
items.description:
When Leyland Kirby announced The Caretaker project was coming to a close, few could have imagined how harrowing the end would be. Everywhere At The End Of Time (Stage 6) evokes the final stage of dementia, when mental processes break down completely. The music is some of the bleakest drone you'll ever hear, with Kirby's ballroom refrains obscured by a terrifying blankness. He calls it "listenable chaos," but that depends on how listenable you find the dissolving of a mind in real-time.

Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

Since she stepped onto the scene, Lafawndah's work has been steeped in the vast world of experimental club music. Her debut album is her most evocative project yet, with soft-spoken but boldly delivered sentiments on geography, identity and intimacy. Merging club, Middle Eastern rhythms, moombahton and pop with sensual R&B vocals, Ancestor Boy draws from global influences without losing its singular appeal. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

We had to wait until November to get what might be 2019's best techno album, a heavy-duty double-pack from Blawan and Pariah. Released eight years after their landmark debut as Karenn, Grapefruit Regret captured what's magical about their raw, energetic sound, perhaps best reflected in the blistering highlight "Crush The Mushrooms." The pair recorded the album's eight tracks during an "intense" studio session, harnessing their extensive modular setup to create an explosive techno record. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Jenny Hval The Practice Of Love  Sacred Bones Records
items.description:
On this striking LP for Sacred Bones, the Norwegian musician and novelist Jenny Hval dismantles abiding notions about love, digging into the historical, psychosexual and political aspects of this most essential part of the human experience. Her sound of choice is expansive dance pop that nods towards trance's euphoric potential. The combination of these elements is a triumph, an improbable inversion of love's inherent conservatism towards artistic and personal freedom.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

There are no kicks on Sam Barker's debut LP, Utility. And yet, the album is as fit for the club as it is for deep listening, a special balance the Leisure System cofounder achieved only after more than a decade of experimentation. Using unconventional rhythms and sound design, Barker combines the euphoria of trance, the movement of techno, the expansiveness of ambient and the detail of IDM. The result is an impressive challenge to the established dance floor formula.

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

In the age of reissue mania, Fingertracks Vol. 1 felt refreshingly personal, hearkening back to a specific place (Southern California) and time (the mid-to-late '00s, when Andrew Hogge shared 1000 deep cuts on lovefingers.org). Lovefingers' original list presaged the sound and attitude of the "selector" movement, but at the end of the day, it was a labor of love. From Italian minimalism to private-press psych, Fingertracks replicates the feeling of listening to records in the living room of a vastly knowledgeable friend. 

Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

When big budgets and big ambitions collide, it's usually a mess. Across a string of excellent records, Flying Lotus has earned the trust to meander off-piste. Flamagra is core FlyLo: funky basswork, zig-zagging beats and sweeping strings are all present. With a starry guest cast that includes Solange, George Clinton and David Lynch, the beatmaker explores moments of lucidity and despondency that occur when you crash back down to earth from a psychedelic high. It makes for one of his most varied and compelling albums to date. 

Listen: Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: MoMA Ready The NYC Dance Project  Self-released
items.description:
